text:
crowd pleaser. everyone always begs for these but i recommend the following:

1. don't use double stuf oreos (they fall apart, it's messy, just don't try it)

2. you can subsitute almond bark for the outer coating, it's delicious.

3. the chocolate outer coating is really really hard to put on the oreo balls so first make sure that you CHILL the balls. then melt the chocolate on low heat or microwave and my method of dipping (so that the balls wouldn't fall apart and get the chocolate all dirty) was to take two spoons and kind of roll it around / spoon chocolate onto the ball.  

(that's because the toothpick into an oreo ball sometimes causes the entire thing to fall apart)

There are so many options with this recipe...

text:
Good recipe - easy to follow and ingredients are non-threatening/easy to find.

A word to the wise.  I'm not great with baking that requires complete attention.  This does!  The part where you cover you Oreo "meatball" in chocolate.  

A few hints: as you melt the chocolate, stir constantly and stop as soon as all of the stuff is melted - even a smidge before you think it's totally done.  Use a slotted spoon and drop the cookie in and pour the chocolate over it.  Move quickly or else the chocolate cools and it's like walking in quicksand.

The toothpick thing didn't work for me and was discouraging in the beginning - despite chilling the stuff it didn't stay together and "muddied" the chocolate. The spoon method was much, much better.

text:
Excellent!  I followed the advice to crush cookies in the processor AND then add the cream cheese via the same way.  You'll know it's well blended when the whole cookie mixture turns into a big blob...it won't be crumbly at all.  I also chilled the dough for about 15 min before rolling.  I then chilled the balls (in the freezer) for about 10 min while I melted the chocolate.  I dipped 1/2 the batch at at time & then melted the remaining 1/2 of chocolate for the 2nd tray of balls.  YUMMY.

text:
I got this recipe for "Oreo Balls" at my cooking club cookie exchange last year and have had HUGE success with them. I made them for my hubby's company picnic and they were so well received that I had people actually asking if they could pay me to make them for their families for the holidays!  The recipe I have is the same as this except it calls for refrigerating the scooped balls for 1 hour before dippings, and also calls for dipping half of them in milk chocolate and half in white chocolate, then drizzling the opposite flavor over the top. (a slotted spoon works really well for both dipping and drizzling) An A+ recipe for sure!

text:
These are great - and a hit at the party!  Really easy to make - I think the dipping worked well with using a teaspoon and fork - resting the truffle on the fork and using the spoon to pour the chocolate over.  I think the trick is to try and handle the truffle as little as possible and trying to keep them at the tip of the fork so that you can slide the fork out without having to touch the truffle when putting it back on the wax paper.  Chilling them for at least an hour helped (I think mine chilled for a little longer than an hour) and I kept them on wax paper on a metal cookie sheet to help keep them cool while I was dipping.  My next ones I'll try with a different cookie - probably nutter butters since after telling guests about this version, I got requests to make them next time with the peanut butter cookies!  I got many compliments so definitely making again :)
They are rich, so you can't have too many of these at one time - but maybe that's a good thing!

These guys are awsome, and great for x-mas gifts. To make the chocolate coating look really gourmet, melt 18 oz of semi-sweet chocolate chips or baking squares with 2 oz of paraffin wax(I use gulf wax found in canning section) and coat as specified in this recipe.  I used a whole package of double stuff mint oreos and they were awesome.  My husband went crazy over them.  Next I will try nutter butter cookies.

text:
These are awesome, and I'm not even a big fan of oreos.  Two tips:  Add 1-2 tablespoons of crisco to your dipping chocolate as you melt it.  The taste will not change, and it helps to liquify the chocolate so it's much easier to dip the balls in.  To dip the balls - break the two middle prongs of a plastic fork and use the fork to remove balls from the melted chocolate.  It's much easier to help remove the extra chocolate using it.  Make sure you allow your balls to set a little in the fridge/freezer before dipping, as others have recommended.  I love using milk choc. chips and white chips.  I dip some in the milk choc. and some in the white, then drizzle the opposite on top.  They really make a nice presentation together on a plate.

country:
None
text:
I found just breaking up the Oreos and then using my stand mixer to mix with the cream cheese worked very well.  In fact, it adds an extra crunch if you eat them soon after mixing and before the cream cheese has had a chance to moisten the Oreos.  When forming the truffles, I use a 1-inch scoop and then wear disposable gloves to form the truffles so the "dough" doesn't stick to my hands.  Then pierce each truffle with a toothpick and freeze for a few hours.  Remove the truffles a few at a time to dip into melted chocolate.  Because the truffles are frozen, the chocolate adheres quickly.  After truffles are coated with chocolate just remove the toothpicks (twist the toothpick and it will just pop out).  I then add a dollop of chocolate to fill in the hole.  Also, remember to add a tablespoon of Crisco to the chocolate to make a better consistency for dipping and it doesn't alter the taste.

text:
A few hints for those unsure... 1. Refrigerate the oreo 'dough' for 1 hour before making them into balls.  It will make the rolling so much easier!  2. I stacked my balls on a paper plate, and then froze them for about 15-20 minutes.  I found that freezing the balls before putting them in scorching hot chocolate made them much easier to handle.  3. Follow the directions on the Bakers chocolate box.  Microwave for 30 seconds on high, then stir, then another 30 seconds plus 10 seconds for each additional square of chocolate you heat up.  Worked perfectly every time, and the people at work are raving about them!

text:
These are fabulous and so easy to make! I made two batches to take to my niece's 11th birthday party this weekend one with oreos and one with nutter butters.  (I couldn't resist sampling one of each.) I definitely recommend a food processor to crush the cookies into fine crumbs - it took no time at all. Also, the slotted spoon method of dipping the truffles AFTER they are CHILLED for at least an hour is a great idea.  To set the chocolate I put the truffles on wax paper and put them in them in the frezzer for a couple of minutes.  This is definitely one for future parties and Christmas.

text:
Really good! I didn't find these much more trouble to make than, say little meatballs. I did refrigerate the dough before making the balls and before coating them with chocolate, and that worked well. Using about 2/3 of a tablespoon each, I ended up with 42 balls. I melted the chocolate in a stainless bowl over simmering water, then turned the heat way down to the lowest setting and left the bowl in place. Drop a ball into the chocolate, flip it with a fork, then use the fork to fish it out. Use a small offset spatula to scrape the excess chocolate from the bottom of the fork then roll the ball onto waxed paper. It took 9 1-ounce squares of chocolate and there was less than 2 tablespoons remaining. I dusted half of them with ground up cookies per the recipe. On the other half, I did white chocolate squiggles. Sister dropped by, "tested" one...then absconded with half of them! They will be going (or so she says) to the quilting class at the local sewing store tomorrow! BTW, the package of Oreos was 1 pound 2 ounces (18 ounces), containing exactly the correct number of cookies (9+36). Glad I didn't eat a couple thinking I would have plenty left for the recipe! All in all, these are well worth the couple hours needed to put them together. The half of the recipe I have left will easily last here for a week or so. I'll try adding a little instant coffee (a tbsp to start) or a couple tbsp of maraschino cherry juice. And I'll try them with the mint or peanut butter cookies as well!

OH MY GOODNESS! I wish I had discovered this sooner. This is SO GOOD, words can't describe. I made 24 balls half white chocolate and the other half with milk chocolate. I used toothpicks and I had no problem, I just threw the ball in there and used a spoon to drizzle chocolate all over. text:
One of my (and my family's) most favorite treats. We absolutely love these frozen. This is great for Halloween (using white baking chocolate in place of the semi-sweet) to make "eyes" or for Christmas cookie platters. These never fail to disappear soon after you make them. This works with any combination of Oreos (or even Nutter Butters!) and baking chocolate. NOTE: It's much easier if you crush your cookies in your food processor, then add your softened cream cheese. It really saves you an added step and a whole lot of mess in the long run. Also, if you chill your truffles for an hour before you dip them in the melted chocolate, they'll coat a lot easier without getting tacky.

text:
I've made these several times now, and I've got it mastered!

Here are my tips:
1) Use a blender or food processor to get your cookies really fine.  It keeps them from crumbling in the chocolate.
2) As soon as you've mixed in the cream cheese, make the balls and put them in the freezer for 30-45 minutes.
3) Use a fondue pot for your chocolate! It keeps the chocolate at the PERFECT temperature without ever having to worry about it burning or having to constantly stir it. 
4) The mint oreos are AMAZING! My favorite variety. Don't use double-stuff, yuck! I also tried Nutter Butters, but they weren't as good as expected. They lost the peanut buttery flavor, so if I tried those again I would reduce cream cheese and add some Jif. 
Good luck!

country:

text:
My cousin made these for her children's birthday about a year ago and I fell in love with it. I've since made this recipe a few times and it is always a crowd pleaser.  I crushed the cookies and mixed the cream cheese in by hand in the past (what a pain!) - this time I used my Ninja food processor. Hello why didn't I do this before? It literally took all of 1 minute.  My food processor crushed the cookies into the texture of graham cracker crumbs (unlike when I was doing it by hand in the past) and I added the softened cream cheese to my processor until it all clumped together into a large blob. Then I used my cookie scoop to measure out uniform truffles. I usually freeze them for a few hours or overnight THEN proceed with coating them in chocolate. The truffles keep their shape and the chocolate hardens quickly. They do defrost quickly once removed from the freezer but not quick enough to make a mess while I'm dipping them in chocolate.  When I'm done, I just refrigerate until ready to serve.

After reading the fab reviews and loving Oreos, I thought I would add this recipe to my Christmas trays. Personally, I thought they tasted like gooey oreos and were not very appealing in texture. I should preface this by saying that I usually make hand dipped truffles with good quality chocolate. This just had a cookie dough consistency that does not appeal to me. I will throw a couple on my trays and whip up some "real" truffles. I wish I would have just hand dipped the whole oreos for a more pleasing outcome.

text:
I have made these for a few yrs now for the holidays and everyone loves them, i recently lost the recipe and was happy someone had put it in here.  I have found if you chill the balls first they coat easier without becoming soft as fast.  IInstead of a fork for dipping,  I let them chill and then use a toothpick inserted to dip and use another to push off onto wax paper.  You can easily go back and "swirl" the chocolate where the hole was left giving it a professional look. I have  also used mint chocolate chips and/or the mint oreos, for a different flavor.  It is a recipe you can easily play around with  to provide a variety without digging up several different recipes to do so.

text:
delicious and simple to make. As I was reading through the reviews, one person said that double stuff oreos won't work because it is too gooey. I was disappointed when I realized that I accidentally bought double stuff. Since I was bored, and wanted to make them, I added 1/2 block of cream cheese instead of the whole thing...this compensated for the extra filling from the cookies, and it had the right consistency! So, if anyone wants to make them but onlyhas double stuffed, just 1/2 the cream cheese and you are good to go!

text:
This was a huge hit during Thanksgiving dinner so I made a few batches for Christmas dinner and presents.  Instead of using an 8 oz. package of cream cheese I used a 12 oz. tub of whipped cream cheese, in addition  I added 4 drops of pure vanilla extract and 1 tablespoon of milk with the whipped cream mix.  Instead of using baker's baking chocolate I used hardening chocolate for ice cream, it was alot easier to cover the Oreo balls that I individually laid on mini cupcake holders.  I made different variations and decorations on each batch for a nice arrangement of truffles.

city:

country:
None
text:
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME!!! This has to be one of the very best recipes i have ever done! We loved them except hubby, he doesnt care for chocolate. I think im going to be making these for Christmas in a few weeks and going to double the recipe, the only problem I really had was dipping the balls into the chocolate. Heres what I did, I took each cookie apart and put the filling in another bowl so that way when I crushed the cookies up they wouldnt get sticky from the filling, then i put the cookies on wax paper, then covered with another sheet and used a glass to crush, took a few minutes, then I put the crumbs in a bowl with the room temp. cream cheese and cookie filling, mixed real well then shaped into little balls and put on a cookiesheet lined with the paper and refrigerated for about an hour then took them out and dipped in the melted choc. it got kinda messy ay this point, Turns out i ended up using chopsticks to dip them in, a few of the balls tried falling apart, but nothing major, after all were dipped, placed them back in the fridge where they now sit with hardened chocolate and ooohh so DELICIOUS!!! Thank you!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made two batches of these truffles. One batch used cream cheese and the other used neufchatel (the lower fat version of cream cheese). I had an awful time trying to coat the batch that used the cream cheese; the truffles fell apart when they hit the chocolate even after they spent the night in the freezer. The batch that had the neufchatel in it stayed together beautifully! I had no trouble coating them in the melted chocolate and they ended up looking like something from a fine chocolatier. Both batches were DELICIOUS, but for the added ease of coating, I would suggest using neufchatel instead of regular cream cheese.

availlancourt

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!  Easy, but a little bit time consuming to make.  I found the easiest way to coat the truffles in chocolate was to: 
1. Rest a truffle on top of 2  skewers (the type you would use for kabobs) with one hand (sort of like balancing a truffle on chopsticks).
2. With a spoon, pour the melted chocolate over the truffle (with the excess falling right back into the pot of melted chocolate)
3. Use both hands (one skewer in each) to lay the truffle on wax or parchment paper.

None
text:
Tips- Freeze the truffles after rolling them into balls for about 45 minutes until they are firm. This makes it much easier to dip in chocolate. Then, instead of using semi sweet chocolate, try using white chocolate. It tastes much better that way. Also, you could try a mint version, using mint chocolate cookies and half of the mint filling and follow the recipe from there. Keep the chocolate-dipped truffles in the freezer until serving time. If you don't want to dip them in chocolate, you could sandwich one in between two square "snaps" pretzels and they are also good.

Really Good and incredibly  easy. city:

country:
None
text:
These were very easy, and so good!  I crushed the oreos in my small food processor, and then mixed them with the cream cheese with my hands.  After rolling them into balls, I froze them on the wax paper covered cookie sheet for a couple of hours.  I used the two toothpick method  for dipping in chocolate, and I dipped half of the batch in white chocolate and the other half in semisweet chocolate.  Then I put the excess chocolates in a ziploc bag, snipped off a corner of the bag and piped white chocolate drizzles on the chocolate covered truffles, and chocolate drizzles on the white chocolate covered truffles.  They were beautiful, and everyone thought I had bought them from a bakery!  They were a hit at the New Year's Eve party!  Thanks for an easy and delicious recipe!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-12-28T09:56:49.927
helpfulCount:
8
userID:
3360303
Display Name:
Karen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
635
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2414.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Always a hit! I crush my cookies in plastic freezer bags using a non-metal meat tenderizer mallet (double bagging the cookies before crushing).  I use 32 Oreos for the "filling" and only 3 for the "sprinkles". The Kraft website directions calls for 3 cups of cookies for the filling and that's what 32 Oreos yields for me. I usually dip mine in white chocolate using the 2 fork method of rolling and picking up and it's the best method I've found so far. I've also dipped these in melted milk chocolate/peanut butter chips, but thought the covering overpowered the Oreo taste (even though my friends inhaled them and said they were awesome). I've also made these using Nutter Butters dipped in milk chocolate, Chips Ahoy White Fudge Chunk dipped in milk chocolate & drizzled with white chocolate, and regular Chips Ahoy dipped in milk chocolate. Basically 3 cups of crushed cookies, a block of cream cheese (1/3 fat works out fine in the recipe too) and some kind of melted chocolate is a winner every time. My "technique": Make sure there are NO loose crumbs after combining cream cheese & cookies (I don't have the benefit of a food processor); Refrigerate cream cheese/cookie mix at least an hour before rolling into balls (2+ hours is best); Use a melon scoop to scoop out dough for balls to get a consistent size; Freeze balls at least an hour before dipping; Sprinkle with crumbs or decorative sprinkles as I dip so chocolate won't harden before I've sprinkled them. They're addicting!

love these recipes. i read about them in some blogs and decided they'd make a cute holiday gift. i used mint oreos and a mix of bakers/confectioners melting chocolate. my only advice is to use the entire package of oreos (don't reserve any for topping, just top with sprinkles!) and maybe 3/4 of the cream cheese... i felt like mine were a little too creamy but perhaps i just over processed the oreos? not sure. my dad raved about these :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5072170.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM! So not healthy for you but a fab treat every once in a while. My Mother-in-law made these for us for a couple of years and I just made some this year for neighbor/friend treats. I found a few key things to do that made them really easy. First of all I ground the oreos in my food processor in batches (my processor isn't big enough to hold them all). Then after trying to mix the oreos with the cream cheese I found it easier and more efficient to mix in my food processor, again in batches. As a previous reviewer suggested when it is really smooth and starts to ball up it is ready. I then chilled for about an hour, rolled them out, chilled again for about 30 minutes and had no problems dipping in the chocolate. The smooth consistency from processing them I really think made all the difference.

Rating:

userID:

Display Name:
bakeaholic

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/466789.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these every holiday season. I use both chocolate and vanilla almond bark instead of real chocolate, as it sets up quicker without using the freezer or refrigerator. I then decorate with a piping bag, and the contrasting color of almond bark to what I coated them in. I find the best way for me to dip the balls in chocolate is to chill them for about 15 minutes, then use a clean toothpick (wiping off the toothpick between each dip). This results in a tiny hole on the top, but I just smear a little chocolate over it with the toothpick before it sets, and you can't tell. Tap the toothpick on the side of the bowl to drain off extra chocolate before removing the truffle. If you drizzle with white almond bark, then sprinkle with holiday colored sugars, they look very pretty. I have even piped stars and swirls and such onto the tops. So easy and fun!

country:
None
text:
A hard chill before rolling into balls and then again before dipping into your coating works best.  Best trick I found was to get lollipop sticks and a block of floral foam.  You can dip 100% of your Oreo ball into your coating and then just stick it in the foam block.  If they are really cold before dipping, it only takes a minute or so to harden.  Remove them to a plate and just keep reusing the sticks until done.  Extremely simple and neat. I do about 8 at a time.  Wonderful!

text:
Very cheap, easy to make, and definitely a crowd pleaser! I used a pack of regular oreos, 1 pkg of cream cheese, and a about 12oz of semi sweet choc chips. The only problem I encountered while making these, the chocolate would harden after a couple minutes, so it would become difficult to cover the truffles with the chocolate. I would recommend melting portions of the chocolate as your dipping. I will definitely be making these again and want to try white choc next time!

text:
this recipe is a favorite with my friends. they always want me to make them whenever i have to bring dessert to a party.. we call them dirty snowballs =] i do two things differently that i think makes them taste a heck of a lot better: i used white chocolate or white almond bark for the coating instead of semi-sweet chocolate. also, i put the uncoated balls in the freezer for at least half an hour before i coat them, then i put them back in the freezer overnight. they taste much much better when they're icy cold... which is why i call them snowballs =D

text:
I've been making these truffles for years and I'm pretty sure my family wouldn't let me in the house at Christmastime without a tin or two in my hand.    I do make a couple of changes, however.  1 package of cream cheese isn't enough.  1 1/2 packages works much better, or if you really like cheesecake, use 2 packages.  I also dip them in white bark, then sprinkle the top with crushed Oreo that I saved at the beginning OR crushed Andes mints!  If dipping is difficult for you, the best way is to break off the center tines of two plastic forks and use those to help you dip them.  No more awkward lumps, bumps, or bare spots!!

userID:
4452626
Display Name:
cjmuehlb
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here is a couple of tricks.  Use a food processor.  The finer the cookie crumble the better it stays together.  Make sure your cream cheese is soft and use your hands to work the cream cheese into the cookie crumbs.  It should end up like dough.  Do not refrigerate the cookie mixture before you roll it into balls, but after. Use a double boiler.  The chocolate will be too thick and you won't get a nice smooth covering if you microwave it.  Put the ball on the fork and lower it into the chocolate then when you bring it out, tap the fork against the side of the pan which will make a more even coating and get rid of excess chocolate.  Rather than sprinkle with cook crumbs, drizzle with white chocolate.  Makes a much prettier truffle.

This has become a favorite at our house. We make these several times a year, but coat them in white chocolate instead of semi-sweet. Usually use almond bark. Tried the dark initially, but prefer the white. Don't set aside 9 cookies to top. 3-4 is more than enough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was all fired up and ready to just slam this recipe since the dipping part initially was a big pain in the a**!!!  However, I stopped and read several reviews and calmed down.  First - these are some of the tastiest morsels you will ever eat, but I had trouble with melting and then coating with white chocolate.  The balls were chilled, but I just couldn't get the stuff to coat and I ended up with a big blob of chocolate. I was using a double boiler also! I transferred the blob to a small dip size crock pot and I added about a tablespoon of shortening; and then it just worked. I gave up on the skewers and just used a slotted spoon and another spoon to coat.  I may try again with the stick since I really wanted a pop presentation.  But the balls are in the fridge now and have hardened beautifully.  Still not as pretty as the pictures, but I topped with colored sprinkles and they look great. I think I will try the melting chocolate from craft stores as others had suggested, but I was determined to use what I had on hand.  I can honestly say, I will make this again, but I'm much wiser  now!

text:
I used reduced fat Oreos and reduced fat cream cheese.  I would only reserve 4 cookies to sprinkle over the dipped truffles.  After balling the dough, I put it in the freezer for about an hour.  I microwaved 16 oz. milk chocolate chips and 1 tablespoon shortening for 20 second intervals until melted.  I dipped the end of a lollipop stick in the melted chocolate and stuck one in each ball.  I then dipped the balls and made truffle lollipops.  Everybody LOVED these!

text:
I chilled the oreo balls for 30 mins, dipped them in chocolate, fished them out with a fork in one hand and a spoon in the other, and then chilled them again for another 30 mins.  It's messy, but deliciously worth it.  There's lots of room for exploration!!  ex. milk chocolate, white chocolate, peanut butter, buttefinger, mint oreos, nuts, etc.

I feel so sophisticated offering people these truffles.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
3 Thumbs Up! My hubby and both boys loved these. Tips for dipping:  chilled oreo/cream cheese mixture 10 mins before rolling into balls. Chilled balls in freezer 30 mins. before dipping.  Stirred in approx. 1/4 tsp. Crisco Oil to melted chocolate. Dropped ball into chocolate, coated with spoon where needed, tapped the dish to get a smooth coat before removing.  Drizzled with milk chocolate.

Very rich.  I used fat free cream cheese.  I put the cream cheese/ oreo crumbs mixture in the freezer for about 30-40 minutes to harden it up.  Then, it was really easy to make the mixture into the  balls.  When I dipped the balls into the chocolate the outer chocolate hardened VERY quickly even while I was finishing the rest of the balls. country:
None
text:
I love these! I've been making these for about two years. I would recommend a couple things. One, use a double boiler (or a bowl inside a pot of boiling water) for melting the chocolate. It is easier to dip them, instead of having to reheat via microwave, and it also helps the chocolate to stay at the right temp. Also, if you're  going to make these with different flavor oreos, we LOVE them with the mint oreos, and then add about half a bag of mint chocolate chips (Andes mints are what we use) in the melted chocolate. Helps bring out the flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SO GOOD!!! and so easy too! These truffles are absolutely delicious! The first time I made these I didn't have a food processor or blender, so I put the cookies in a ziploc and rolled over them w/a rolling pin. This works ok, but I would recommend crushing half at a time if you do it this way. The second time I made them I used my blender, and the cream caused it to keep stopping because everything was stuck in the blade. My solution: put small batches in a ziploc and crush, then in the blender to finish it off. (unless someone wants to buy me a food processor-I'm sure it's much easier)

Sooo good!  I decided to expand upon the recipe and try them with Mint Oreos!  Something about the "stuffing" is different than with the regular Oreos, so you need to use more wafers (scrape the stuffing off about 9 more cookies) or dough will be too gooey. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these several times and love them! My tricks are to first, roll all of the oreo mixture into the balls and put on the cookie sheet and then into the fridge for about 1 hour. 
Then I pull out my handy dandy wilton chocolate melter pot thing and get the chocolate started. (It's great because it keeps it at the perfect tempered temperature.) Then I pull out the balls and dip them into the chocolate doing 2 rows then putting them back into the fridge for 20 minutes. Repeat this until done. This keeps the oreo stiff enough to hold up to the chocolate when dipping. DON'T put them into the freezer, they will sweat and become soft when you take them out. When just using the fridge I have found that the chocolate keeps that satisfying crunch no matter how long they have been sitting on the table. ***Also, make sure your chocolate is warm enough because if it isn't tempered it will coat the oreo balls too thickly thus creating a soft exterior.***

text:
I needed to bring something for a baby shower at work. However, I didn't feel like buying any pricey ingredients and I had limited time, so I decided to try these. Everyone in the office LOVED them! Multiple people asked me for the recipe. I was tempted to tell them something overly complex, but decided not to lie since a million hits come up when you Google "Oreo Truffles."

On the advice of other reviewers, I froze the balls before spooning the chocolate over them. I made some with semi-sweet chocolate and some with white chocolate. I added canola oil to the melted chocolate to make it easier to spoon over the balls and to make the chocolate look prettier. I only melted a little chocolate at a time, so I didn't have to worry about it hardening too quickly.

Display Name:
eandlrich

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I got this recipe years ago calling for almond bark, but the bakers squares work also. Covering the entire ball works best for me if I chill the balls in the freezer 10-20 minutes, then inserting a toothpick, dip & cover, let the excess dip fall and then stand the dipped ball in a piece of styrofoam. (I now save all styrofoam when I buy anything packed in a box like my last printer!) Once they are all dipped and and stuck, the whole thing can be set in the refrigerator. Toothpicks can be pulled out after the dip has hardened. If I find I need to melt more bark before I'm done, I put the undipped ones back in the freezer until I'm ready. If they are not chilled long enough, they won't stay on the toothpick without falling. I tried mint double stuff and it works, but required more time. I had to freeze the dough 10-20 minutes to make the rolling easy, then freeze 10-20 minutes after rolled to make the dipping easy, then refrigerate. They should also be kept chilled (especially double stuff ones) because they longer they sit at room temperature, they become very very gooey. They tasted better chilled to with the mint. My friend tried using nutter butters and they were NOT good. They tasted more like play dough than a cookie!
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
7693239
Display Name:
jesstsilly
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since coming across this great & simple recipe, I have made at least a dozen different batches & has been a hit at work & parties.  Women say they are orgasmic. :)  How can you go wrong.  Like other reviewers I always chill them first.  I don't chill before rolling them with my 5yr old little helper.  I pop them in the freezer for a while & then transfer to the fridge prior to dipping.  I use a strong plastic fork with the 2 middle prongs removed (just bend them back and break off).  

I also like to mix my chocolates and use a variety for dipping, chocolate almond bark, then add both dark & milk choco candy bars & chips.

I also line a cookie sheet & sprinkle excess cookie crumbs to help the bottoms from sticking.  I tap the dipped truffle on the side of  the pot to remove excess chocolate & just drop onto the sheet.  I usually only take out about 6 from the fridge at a time so they stay chilled.  You may have areas of uncovered truffle, just use the tip of the fork to recover the areas.  I then sprinkle each one with extra crumbles, nuts, decorating colored sugar or powdered sugar...be creative.  After I have a cookie sheet filled I then pop them back in the fridge to cool again.  My 5 yr old does not like minty things, but loves the Mint Oreo Truffles.

Anytime I have taken these to a gathering, there are never any left.  So leave a few at home for yourself to enjoy later.  This is now one of my staple recipes I take to all parties at their request :-)

ENJOY!!!!

text:
Got this recipe from my cousin at Christmas and have made it several times. Actually won first prize at our church's chocolate buffet for Valentines Day. I think people are trying to make them much too difficult.  I did use the regular Oreos but want to try the double stuff and different flavors.  I put 5 at a time in the blender, dumped each batch into a bowl and then added the softened cream cheese. A pastry blender worked great to mix together and then used a cookie scoop to make the balls. That makes them very uniform and your hands aren't in them so much.  I then round them and squeeze to make them stick together good.  Chill well. I used just almond bark to dip and they were fantastic.  I found the toothpicks were a pain so after the first time just used 2 forks and put them on waxed paper.  So many possibilities of variations.  Use your imagination.

I have been making this recipe for years (using the full package of regular Oreos, not double stuff), only I dip in melted white chocolate or almond bark, then drizzle milk or dark chocolate over (using a plastic bag with a hole in one corner), giving them a very professional look.  The best way I have found to dip is to do one side, let it harden, then dip the other side and then lay them on the original flat side created by the first dip.

Love this recipe, and have made it at least 10-12 times so far.  I crush the Oreo's in one of those nut choppers you push down on with your hand. None
text:
I have been making these for years & these truffles are probably the reason I keep getting invited to christmas parties. Everyone loves them!
A few tricks I've learned:
1. Food processor for the oreos. Then I knead in the cr cheese by hand.
2. Place balls on a cookie sheet in the freezer for 15 min before coating.
3. USE VANILLA CANDY COATING / ALMOND BARK. (Not white chocolate.) It is much easier to work with and solves the problem of them tasting too rich.

text:
These were such a hit!!!  

I used the holiday oreos with red filling thinking it would be more festive, not knowing that once everything is mixed up, you can't see the color of the filling...it's just all dark brown goodness.  

So so so so SO GOOD!

I followed someone elses advice and froze the balls prior to dipping, as well as using two spoons instead of toothpicks.  

Also, I used ghiradeli chocolate!  Mmmmmmm...

country:
None
text:
Oh. My. Gosh. Love this recipe. I just wanted to make a dessert and didn't want to do cookies again. Found this recipe...it is a KEEPER! My new go-to for sweets. I followed other advice #1, chill to "dough" after mixing. #2, I mixed it up a little and added half regular Oreos and half Golden Oreos. #3 I melted the chocolate in a glass bowl over simmering water. It worked great at keeping the chocolate melted while dipping the balls. #4 I used a serving size spoon with holes to put the ball on, used a regular spoon to scoop the melted chocolate over it, then used a fork to move the ball to the wax paper. A little messy, but that's totally okay with me.
It's a hit with everyone who's tried it so far!

text:
I made these in 2 batches using Newman's Organic O's in original and mint flavored...both were a big hit! I replaced the semi-sweet chocolate with Ghirardelli bitter-sweet chocolate....amazing! Definitely use a food process for the blending of the cookies and cream cheese. It was easier to mold the truffles if you let the mixture sit in the fridge for 20-30mins. I also let the truffles sit in the fridge for about 4hrs before I dipped them in the chocolate. Using a double boiler for the chocolate made the dipping process pretty painless. Easy & tastythanks for sharing!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Made these once as directed, but they were too chocolately for me. Made a second time with an equivalent amount of Nutter Butter cookies (about 26 for the filling if anyone's wondering), dipped in melted semi-sweet baking chips, and then rolled in either butterfinger crumbs, skor pieces, or white fudge pretzel pieces.  I would recommend using the Baker's chocolate as directed, as I found that the melted chocolate chips were too thick for dipping (kind of had to plunge in and then scrape off excess).  I also highly recommend those three toppings, as they are delicious, easy, and look great too.  However, this recipe is too dense/rich for my taste.  It's kind of funny to watch people's faces when they take too big of a bite out of these.  They are better when they're cold though, and I think they're also better after a day or two in the fridge.  Definitely have a beverage at the ready when eating these!  Oh, and the short ingredient list is still a plus.

dateLastModified:
2011-01-04T15:41:21.413

userID:
6267454
Display Name:
Patty
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

0
madeRecipesCount:
19
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1026541.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This simple recipe is both cheap to make and tasty!  I used reduced fat cream cheese and oreos.  I also used 4 huge (movie-size) bars of Symphony chocolate instead of the Baker's.  Using a double boiler, I broke up all of the chocolate in the pot and then turned the heat on.  As it says in the review below, make sure to turn the heat off as soon as it's melted.  Instead of using toothpicks or spoon, I used tongs, and it was a breeze to clean up.
Review:
Rating:
3

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are to die for.  I have been making these for years.  If you have not made them - give them a try - you will be glad you did.  Here are a few tried and true shortcuts.  I use my food processor (this helps to make the oreos crumbs fine) also cuts the prep time in half.  I always refrigerate the balls first on a wax paper covered cookie sheet (for about 30 minutes). Then to cover them - I use  chocolate almond bark (you can find at wal-mart) it really melts and covers well.  Dipping the cold balls in the chocolate helps it set fast. Also,  I usually only get about 30 from the recipe (not 42 as the recipe shows)

text:
These are amazing. It's pretty essential to chill the Oreo mixture before rolling into balls, and then chilling again before dipping into the melted chocolate. I just balanced each truffle on a spoon, rolled in chocolate, then pushed it off the spoon onto wax paper with a chopstick. I used a high-quality blender and the mix didn't stick at all. Brought them to the office for Christmas and got rave reviews.

We do these with mint oreos too. Be sure to make them SMALL... bite sized. Secrets to not pulling your hair out. Mix all ingredients and chill...being in MN I stick them outside for 5-10 minutes but a freezer will work too. Awesome taste and relatively easy to do. I made them into balls & then refrigerated overnight. text:
My husband and I loved these and he loved them more than I did' only because of the mess they were to make.  (that is why I gave them 4 stars) I highly encourage letting the cookie/cream cheese mixture sit in the freezer for a while (I went and did another whole cookie recipe)  Then I was able to role them in a ball and pierced them with a skewer stick to dunk in the warm chocolate mixture; and because they were plenty cool and firm they did not melt into the warm chocolate.  I kept them in a airtight container in a cool pantry room and they kept for a long time and were very tastey little treats.

text:
These are great tasting and really pretty but they lose a star for being a pain. I use chocolate chips instead of the chocolate, but it was way thick and didn't want to make a nice thin coat. I finally just dipped it in a little chocolate, then rolled it around between gloved palms to smear it, then rolled it colored sugar or cookie crumbs.... only way to get them remotely pretty. It does work better to work with the balls frozen. These are yummy and pretty but EASY is a lie.

text:
Absolutely easy.  I refrigerated the balls while I melted the chocolate.  Don't melt all your chocolate at once.  I used semi sweet baking chips and didn't need two whole 8 oz bags.  I used a regular fork to dip the balls into the chocolate but too much chocolate kept sticking to the fork.  I had a disposable plastic fork so I broke off the two inside tines and it worked perfectly like a professional candy coating fork.  Made the job simple!

None
text:
Super easy and really delicious and rich!  I think I may have seen it mentioned in another comment but putting the chocolate in a slow-cooker was a great approach.  Break up the chocolate as much as you can then add to the slow-cooker.  Bring the heat up to high and cover stirring every few minutes until smooth.  Then drop a well chilled truffle into the pot, roll around with a spoon until coated, remove with a spoon and drop on waxed paper to let it cool.  Worked out great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really easy and yummy.  Not that messy if you do the following: Put the 36 Oreos in a large plastic heavy duty freezer bag. Finely crush them with a rolling pin and then add the cream cheese.  Massage the bag until well mixed.  Use a 1" scoop to form the balls inside the bag (I used the Pampered Chef scoop) .  Do refrigerate the balls before dipping in chocolate.  Use a spoon to plop and cover the balls with chocolate and pick up with a slotted spoon or fork.  I drizzle the white chocolate on top- not as messy as sprinkling the crushed Oreos and it looks prettier!  This year for Christmas I will top with crushed peppermints.   Seriously, I barely had messy hands using this method and less clean up!!

text:
These are very, very rich and delicious. I love Oreo cookies and this recipe is another way to enjoy them. I tried the toothpick idea that other reviewers suggested when it came to dipping the truffles but I didn't have much success. I still had some of my son's old infant spoons so I would drop the truffle into the chocolate, then place it on the baking sheet and then smooth it out a bit with the baby spoon. Instead of dipping them all in semi-sweet chocolate, I dipped some in white chocolate. I also rolled a few in powdered sugar and some in cocoa powder. I plan on making a large batch for Christmas!

text:
So easy!! Every time I bring these I get asked for the recipe. I have made the with every flavor that oreo makes. They are very good with original dipped in white almond bark. YUM!! Make sure to use two spoons to roll the balls around in the chocolate. I did this for the first time and don't know why I didn't do it sooner. I have always refrigerated them and then used a toothpick to assist in the coating process. My son and I did three batches in a half an hour!! I will never think twice about making these because of time.

text:
The recipe is indeed easy to make.  Refrigeration of the dough before making the balls and then again before dipping into the melted chocolate, as recommended by other users, does make the job easy.  The treats were actually fun to make.

But it just did not taste that great.  I had higher expectations from a 5 star rated recipe.  The chocolate coating is tasty.  The inside is not.  The combination is so so.   The thicker the coating the better they taste.  The inside would benefit from better ingredients.  

I recently made better truffles using another recipe.  I believe that you cannot go wrong with simple and tasty ingredients such as dark chocolate, heavy cream and butter instead of cookies and processed cheese.

text:
I decided to make this for Valentines Day and all of my friends loved it! Everyone asked for the recipe! I do have to say that it was kind of difficult to roll the balls in the chocolate. So make sure you put them in the freezer for 15-20 minutes before you roll them in the chocolate. I also dipped half of the ball in the chocolate because it was easier for me. If you want the whole ball to be covered in chocolate then I suggest to dip it in the chocolate, put it on the wax paper and add chocolate to the part of the ball that was not dipped.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I wanted to make a 'test run' with these and make 10 at first instead of 42. So i used 2oz cream cheese and 4.5 peanut butter OREO'S cookies. I crushed the oreos in the food processor. I put the cream cheese in the microwave for 10 seconds then just mixed that in with a spoon to the oreos. Then I chilled in the fridge for 30mins and then the mixture was very easy to work with. I chilled another 30mins after making the balls, then rolled them around in melted chocolate, added some cookie crumbles on top, and left them in the fridge over night. VERY EASY AND DELICIOUS! Will be making these again with a variety of combinations (different cookies, rolled in walnuts, coconut...etc).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
==EDITED==

This is one of my go-to recipes. My gained wisdom:

Instead of using Oreos, use Famous Chocolate Wafers (http://www.amazon.com/Famous-Chocolate-Wafers-9-Ounce-Boxes/dp/B000FA38ZE). Tastes like the cookie part only of Oreos without the filling--makes it extra chocolatey and dense, and less sweet. 

For the topping, instead of the crushed cookies, I use a fork to drizzle melted white chocolate, then sprinkle SEA SALT or other large grained salt. It looks GORGEOUS and so professional, and the salt makes it 3x as delicious.

Best way to dip truffles: CHOPSTICKS. If you are proficient with chopsticks (as I am), this is by far the fastest and neatest way to do it.

More variations:

filling:
crushed toffee, single nut in center, crushed toasted nuts, liqueurs (orange, coffee)

outside:
crushed toasted nuts
cocoa powder
toasted coconut
powdered sugar
white vanilla candy dip (looks great with the dark filling)

Delicious, beautiful yet easy to make.  A little time consuming to make them really pretty but so worth the effort. I made them the first time as instructed with a full pkg of cream cheese but found the balls too soft and mushy. I adjusted the amount to 1/2pkg and i make two different flavors with one pkg. text:
I use white melting chocolate and use chocolate sprinkles for the top. After rolling the balls, I place a toothpick into each one and place in the freezer for a short time.  The toothpicks make for easy dipping into the melted chocolate and much less trouble than forks. Remove the toothpick after dipping, by pressing another toothpick against it, and place a drip of chocolate to hide the hole, place your sprinkles over this area. Chocolate is easily melted for 30 seconds at a time in the microwave, stirring between intervals. These are beautiful, everyone loves them and can't believe they only have 3 ingredients!! LOVE this recipe, Enjoy!!!!

text:
Roll them small, they are rich!  Also, 9 oreos for topping ended up being too much for me.  Based on reviews I refrigerated the mix for about 20 minutes before forming the truffles, then placed on a wax lined cookie sheet in the freezer for 30 minutes.  A double boiler will help keep your chocolate the right temp.  Too warm and it will cause the truffles to fall apart.  I worked in small batches - took 6 out of the freezer at a time.

Display Name:
HoiLei

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We made the inner part of the truffles one night, and dipped them the next morning.  Our experience: a potato masher did a good job breaking up the cookies since we lacked a food processor.  The Oreo/cream cheese mix was oily, but not hard to work with when room temp.  We rolled the balls without much trouble, then refrigerated them overnight.  The next day, the balls were cold and hard--ideal for dipping.  To dip them, we melted the chocolate over a double boiler, and kept it just hot enough to steam and pour, but not so hot it might melt the balls.  We put one ball at a time into a slotted spoon, and scooped a little chocolate from the double-boiler on top of each and rolled it around.  We put the wet truffles onto a greased cookie sheet, then refrigerated them a half hour.  The result: delicious!  The cheese had thoroughly blended with the cookies overnight, so the insides of the truffles are creamy and soft.  What a hit!

text:
Everyone loves these. If you make them with double-stuffed oreos the filling will be really soft and creamy. I also like to make different flavors. I've added crushed walnuts, shredded coconut and finely chopped maraschino cherries to the cream cheese and cookie mixture before rolling them into balls. Cherry tastes wonderful dipped in dark chocolate rather than semi-sweet. When I can find the mint oreos I make mint oreo truffles simply by substituting the regular oreos with mint oreos and dipping them in melted mint chocolate chips.

text:
I made two different batches of these. One was just the regular cream cheese and Oreos. The other was a cream cheese, Oreos, and peanut butter mix, with a peanut butter and chocolate coating. MMMmm they both came out amazing! VERY sweet though. 
After mixing the cream cheese and Oreos together I threw the bowl in the freezer for a little while to harden a bit first. It makes it A LOT easier to dip in the chocolate when they are more firm. 
I melted the chocolate in the microwave.. you might want to let that cool off a little bit first before dipping them too. 
I don't think you really need to crush 9 whole cookies to sprinkle on top.. maybe just 5?
All in all these were delicious!

This recipe is delicious and easy to make.  With all the Oreo flavor variations, there are many different ways to go with this recipe. If you are only dipping the tops, seven cookies is enough to set aside.  These are delicious!

text:
Loved it!!  I mixed the cookies in the food processor, then I put into my stand mixer to add the cream cheese.  The 'dough' formed the balls nicely immediately after mixing.  Then, I put the balls in the freezer for about 3 hours.  I used almond bark (melted in a double boiler - which I HIGHLY recommend) to coat.  I stuck a toothpick into the frozen ball, dipped/swirled into the melted choclate, pulled off the toothpick by turning the coated ball upright (w/the toothpick coming out of the bottom), putting the toothpick between the times of the fork and slowly pulling UP with the fork.  Then, I eased the ball off of the fork onto waxed paper.  Since the balls are frozen, the coating sets up pretty quickly.  I drizzled melted Chocolate almond bark for aesthetics.   They look AND taste great!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-03-11T15:56:41.81

country:
None
text:
These are so yummy and make a great gift, especially at Christmastime. I refrigerated the cream cheese and crumb combo for a day or two prior to coating with chocolate, but that was because I was distracted by other holiday preparations.  However, the firmness of the mix helped in making the little spheres.  I used a mix of chocolate chips and squares of baking chocolate, and I felt that it was too thick to dip the balls in, so I added a little unsalted butter and that helped greatly.  I'm not a fan of using wax or coating chocolate... I find it too waxy tasting or feeling.  Butter work really well, but I did keep all the treats in the refrigerator until time to eat them or give them away, they would have softened up too much at room temperature.

Display Name:
RABBITINA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great and easy recipe! I tried to make this a little more low-fat by using reduced fat Oreos and light cream cheese. I think you cannot taste any difference! I used all the Oreos, not reserving the 9 crushed cookies, and used a hand mixer to blend the crumbs and cream cheese. I rolled the cookie mixture into balls and put them in the freezer on a tray for about 30 minutes. For chocolate (instead of Bakers semi-sweet), I used the meltable candy-making milk chocolate wafers you can buy at craft stores or party stores.  I find melting chocolate chips makes for a grainy mess and I didn't have bakers chocolate.  The melting wafers made it so much easier.  I used the technique where I placed the Oreo ball on a fork and used a tablespoon to coat the ball right over the bowl of melted chocolate. Then I transferred the coated ball to the wax paper with a toothpick.  The chocolate hardened quickly, and I opted to take out the toothpicks.  This left a small hole on top of each truffle, so I made some white decorator icing and covered the top with a white swirl.  They look professional and taste awesome!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/762475.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these a few times now. Every time I make them, I double the recipe and they get gobbled up quickly. I always get requests for the recipe/ to make them again for other get-togethers. I use both white and milk chocolate chips and both combos taste great. It is a little bit time consuming but well worth it. I would suggest firming up the balls before dipping them in the fridge so they don't fall apart and make sure the chocolate is smooth before dipping so that the end product isn't clumpy. All in all, great recipe! Make sure you have milk on hand cause these things are rich.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I threw the cream cheese in the processor after I made a mess trying to mix the crumbles and cheese in a bowl. It mixed perfectly when turned on low. When covering the balls, I tried a fork and a spoon and eventually ended up just using two spoons. Definitely chill the balls for about 15 minutes before dunking. I left half of the batch in the refrigerator while I covered the first half with chocolate. The balls are much less mushy this way. I also drizzled them with white chocolate since I don't like the look of the crumbled oreos. I made the mistake of using the microwave to heat up the white chocolate and ended up burning it so I tried again using the double boiler method. I'm messy when I cook, so I was completely covered in chocolate before they were finished! This was too much fun to make!!

text:
Easy, fun, and delicious! Everyone loves these! I didn't have any trouble with the truffle falling apart during the dipping process...I chilled the balls in the fridge for an hour before dipping, used forks to scoop out of chocolate, and placed in little truffle baking cups. I used my food processor to crush the cookies and only used 34 cookies. I then used my mixer with the cookie paddle to mix the cream cheese in with the Oreo crumbs. Dough formed into balls easily. My 3 year old daughter helped for the balls. I told her just like rolling play-dough!  It was a fun project for us to do.

Display Name:
Gr8momto4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are VERY good and extremely easy to make. I made the recipe as stated and ADDED 1 1/2 teaspoons of Vanilla. I didn't have to refrigerate my dough prior to rolling into balls like many of the other reviews. I used a melon baller to get uniform size balls. After forming into balls I did refrigerate for maybe 20 minutes just to set back up after warming in my hands. It wasn't very messy coating these with chocolate either. I didn't use the famous "spoon" method. I had one clean hand to pick up the new balls and place into the chocolate bowl and my other hand rolled the ball around in the chocolate, once coated I picked up with my fingers and shook to get excess off and placed onto wax paper lined cookie sheet. Then drizzled with white chocolate. VERY good and they melt in your mouth. Thanks for the recipe, I will be making these again.

text:
Super easy to make.  Just be sure to chill the balls before putting the melted chocolate on.  Definitely use two spoons to get the chocolate on the ball.  Place the ball on the spoon and use the 2nd spoon the pour the chocolate. Then pass the ball to the other spoon.  This will keep the ball from falling apart.

text:
Easy to make and yummy to eat. BONUS: They LOOK like they took a lot of effort! I only save 4-5 cookies for the topping. That is more than enough. I crush oreos a couple handfuls at at time in a blender. It goes super fast. While I'm doing that, I let the baking chocolate melt in my mini crockpot. The chocolate melts smooth and stays melted as I dip the oreo balls. I've never refrigerated the balls prior to dipping (why add an extra step & more time?). I've never had a problem just dipping them at room temp.

Great recipe! My aunt gave it to me. Just a few hints that I find helpful. When rolling the mixture into balls, I like to use gloves. It doesnt stick to the gloves, like it does on your hands. After rolling, place on a pan and place them in the freezer. It helps them from falling apart when you coat them with the chocolate.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These are sooo good. Very rich, but a great gift for any chocolate lover! I used my smallest cookie scoop (abt a tbsp and a half) to make them all the same size. Wish I had an even smaller one because these are almost too rich to eat a whole one by yourself at the size suggested. I didn't have any problems forming them into balls right after mixing it all together, but I did refrigerate them for a couple of hours after forming into balls.  I used Hershey's Milk Chocolate Chips. The chocolate bark didn't work well for me. It hardened to quickly because I was dipping cold truffles into it. It took me a couple tries to get them pretty when I was pulling them out of the chocolate. Don't get discouraged... it just takes a little practice. (My hubby didn't mind eating the "ugly" ones! Ha ha)   These taste best if you leave them sit out for 10-15 minutes before eating. Using forks to pull out of the melted chocolate worked great! These were even better the next day when the cookie crumbs had a chance to soften. ***UPDATE 01-18-11*** Bought a 1.5 tsp scoop. PERFECT SIZE! You might wanna halve the batch because this smaller scoop made almost 100 truffles (I think it was like 94).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these and they were super easy!  I was a little worried about covering them in chocolate after reading all of the reviews, but my method worked wonderfully.  I ended up getting 48 balls out of this recipe.  First I allowed the balls to chill for 2 hours.  You probably don't need that long, but I had other things to do and the timing worked out perfectly.  I melted the baker's chocolate in a glass bowl in the microwave per the instructions on the box.  I only melted one box at first, and it ended up covering the majority of the balls.  In the end, I ended up using 2 additional squares from the second box, & it was the perfect amount, but if you want to be sure you will definitely have enough chocolate I would recommend using 3 squares from the second box.  To cover the balls in chocolate I simply put the ball in the bowl of melted chocolate, used a spoon to stir it around & cover it, then fished it out using the spoon and placed it on the cookie sheet & wax paper.  I sprinkled crushed oreos on top of 24 of them, then I melted some white chocolate and used a ziploc bag to drizzle the other 24 with white chocolate.  Both kinds turned out beautifully!  These things are delicious, look like you bought them at a gourmet chocolate shop, and are a guest favorite!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love it - especially when I use the mint oreos and the white chocolate! (Peanut butter also is a nice change).  We had a difficult time at first dipping the truffles and making them look nice, but I think we've found a system.  After creating the balls, put them in the freezer for at least 20 minutes.  Cover a piece of foam (crafting or one out of an appliance box will do) with waxpaper, use toothpicks to pierce the bottom of the ball and dip while still cold, then poke into the foam to cool.  We started pulling from the freezer in small batches and it worked much better.  The truffles weren't falling apart in the chocolate and the coat was much nicer and smoother.  Very easy to pop out the toothpick.  We also liked to drizzle with another chocolate to differentiate between flavors.

text:
Maybe it's because this was my first time making truffles but these were not worth all of the effort.  The centers were difficult to work with as they had the consistantcy of bread dough only oilier and not as stiff.  When I tried to coat them with chocolate they started slipping throuht the lines of the fork which would cause bits of it to fall into the chocolate and being so fine, would have to be mixed in.  I ended up using a spoon and just spread chocolate while they were still on the wax paper which I could only do after being in the fridge all day so that they were hard enough but after 14 or so minutes, they would go back to being doughy.  I couldn't coat the bottoms unless I went back and did it after they had hardened.  It was extremely messy and I will most likely not be using this recipe again.

text:
These are fantastic, and so easy.  I was afraid they would be too sweet, but they were just perfect.  One note - don't try to make double the recipe in one bowl.  Make one batch at a time.  I tried to save time (even though they are quick to make anyway), and it was impossible to mix them properly, so I had to keep them in the freezer so they wouldn't fall apart.  Stick to one batch at a time and they are perfect.

text:
These truffles are absolutely PERFECT!  I didn't reserve extra crumbs for decorating, but I did coat in dark chocolate almond bark and drizzle with white chocolate.  I will probably do the opposite next time as I think white chocolate/white almond bark would taste delicious on these already awesome candies.  The almond bark is a bit cheaper and it is fast to simply pop it in the microwave for a quick melting.  I made them for my family and my husband's family at Thanksgiving, and they were devoured before I could get out of the kitchen.  If the cookie/cream cheese mix is too soft, pop it in the fridge for about 20 minutes before rolling them into balls.  Although the balls will look small when you first make them up, they really get bigger when they are dipped in chocolate.  These are definetly going to be a regular addition to my Christmas candy plates.  (I am making them with peppermint bark, peanut butter ritz dipped in chocolate, chocolate pretzels, and "puppy chow" mix)  Since making the oreo truffles for my family, several of them have already made it again for themselves at home.  I thought I love peanut butter balls the best, but oreo truffles are now my favorite holiday treat!

userID:
4123893
Display Name:
Kristy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The balls are good but I didn't give it a 5 star because I find it simply taste like an "Oreo"!!  Nothing special.  I used the exact ingredients stated in the recipe.  I did the following and they were not messy at all and perfect in appearance.  1.)  I used my food processor to chop the oreos then I added the Cream cheese to the food processor.  I left it on chop until all of the oreos were completely mixed with the cream cheese.  2)  Using a 1 tbsp measuring spoon, I scooped a heaping spoonful of mixture (packing it against the side of the bowl) then popped it out on the edge of the ball.  I placed them on a tray covered in wax paper.  I then stuck toothpicks in them to allow me to hold it while dipping.  3 )I put them in the freezer for about 45 minutes.  4) After freezing, melt chocolate in a dish deep enough to cover the ball when dipped.  I used a measuring cup.  Melt chocolate only until smooth (in attempt to keep the temperature as low as possible).  5) ONLY remove a few balls at a time.  Use toothpick to dip into chocolate.  Place on a tray.  6) Sprinkle crushed oreos on top while chocolate is still soft (bc they will not stick later).    7) Once balls have hardened, gently pull out toothpicks.  Suggestion:  Do not leave balls on counter too long.  If you keep them i the refrigerator, they will hold and remain hard enough to eat without messy fingers!!!  ENJOY!

text:
mhmmm! I love, LOVE these oreo truffles. I would make these all the time if I could! :) BUT here is what I did:
I crushed about 32 oreo cookies for the mixture, and three more for the topping. I used a 12 ounce pack of the semi-sweet chocolate instead. It was ALMOST enough (I had rolled 54 balls from the oreo+cream cheese batter/mix, but my mother kept taking my oreo & cream cheese balls!!)  for melting the chocolate, I had a medium saucepan about 1/3 full of water, and put a bowl on top to melt my chocolate in. I put about 5 of the balls into the bowl of chocolate, and used a rubber spatula to cover them with chocolate (& make sure that you hurry bc it starts to fall apart, and the chocolate hardens!) I used a fork to grab it and put it onto mini cupcake liners. I was able to dip about only 38 of the balls into the melted semi-sweet chocolate the rest had disappeared. I had topped mine off with oreo crumbs, melted white chocolate, melted white chocolate and oreo crumbs, and some I just left without toppings.

This recipe is really sweet, and goodness, it's so easy to do with so little ingredients. I will definitely make more in the future!

These are delicious and a big hit with my husband. He actually brought the recipe to me one day and asked me to make it. He had it at a get together with other soldiers. This is the second time I've made it. The only thing sort of confusing about this recipe on here is that a regular thing of oreos doesn't have as many oreos in it as the recipe says. It says crush 9 oreos, set aside, and then crush remaining 36 oreos. text:
So easy and everyone always LOVES these - they never last more than a day.  I just throw an entire bag of oreos (usually double stuff since that's what we buy) in a ziplock freezer gallon bag - and smash away.  Then I throw it in a bowl with a block of cream cheese.... electric mixer... They are ready to roll right away.  I don't know if its the extra oreos or what, but I've never had a hard time rolling them in the chocolate.  Sometimes I'll roll them all out, and pop the pre-rolled balls in the fridge while I melt the chocolate (but not necessary) - just helps the chocolate set faster.

Easy and delicious!

text:
So dangerously delicious! I made these at Christmas time and haven't stopped craving them since. The extra crushed Oreos that you sprinkle on top isn't necessary But it does look prettier. You have to make sure you sprinkle it right after you dip the Oreo balls in the chocolate though, or else it dries too fast and it won't stick to the chocolate. You don't need near as much chocolate as it says to coat the Oreo balls with either. I made a batch with regular Oreos and another with mint Oreos. They were just Kroger brand Oreos too and they were so good! I think I almost liked the mint ones even better. I made 1/4 batch today since we had some Oreos and cream cheese on hand. (Didn't want to get carried away and gain a ton of weight again)! :) I used 2 ounces of cream cheese and 9 Oreos and 1 little square of almond bark. I didn't use any Oreos to sprinkle on top this time. I formed them into 13 little balls with this batch. Can't wait to eat them!!! :)

Delish!  I chill the mixture before rolling into balls, then freeze the balls before dipping.   Adds to the prep time, but makes it easy.  I usually end up melting more chocolate for dipping than the recipe calls for.  The sprinkled crumbs on top didn't stick well for me, so I just skip that part.

text:
Super recipe. If chocolate stiffens add a small swirl of honey and reheat and it should bring it back to smooth consistency. Also, for a more holiday taste you can use "peppermint or regular mint" oreos in the mix. Also, try using white chocolate for any that are allergic to the semi sweet or dark varieties.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these for the second time and they are even better.  It definitely helps to let the mixture sit before you roll it into balls, it wasn't as gooey and easier to work with.  I also let them sit in the fridge for an hour before I dipped them. Putting about 1 tablespoon of Crisco helps the chocolate melt smoother (I used almond bark).  Using 2 forks to dip is something I wish I would've done the first time around: so much easier and not as messy! Hope this helps, enjoy!

Display Name:
What's for dinner, mom?
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3274570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS!  Made these with my son's girlfriend.  They came together quickly as I used the food processor to crush the cookies.  This gave a even, smooth texture to the truffles.  We blended the cookies and cream cheese in the mixer and made the texture even more creamy. I used candy making discs by Wilton, in vanilla and milk chocolate.  The vanilla was so pretty with the cookie crumbles on top! We did think that 9 cookies for the topping was WAY too much with all we had left over.  Would reduce that to 4 cookies next time and just add the rest to the cream cheese mixture. 
I recommend popping the formed balls into the freezer for 15 minutes prior to dipping.  This helps the chocolate to stick much better.  We used 2 forks to dip and transfer the coated balls.  Worked far better than a toothpick!  No doubt these will be made often!

text:
Theses truffles are delicious! And very simple to make. I made a few changes that work great. 1. After forming the balls I freeze them for 20 minutes so they are nice and cold when trying to dip them in the chocolate. 2. I have also used Bakers dipping chocolate that comes in the microwaveable cup instead of the semi-sweet. It taste great and the chocolate dries rather quickly. 3. I only use the double stuff oreos since they taste creamer and they turn out the same as the originals.

These are fantastic and easy to make!!! Erin Wyatt

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2876376.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OH MY GOSHHH!! These are so awesome--and easy!! Lately, I've been fixated on making cake balls (per Bakerella book Cake Pops) but they take hours to make. These truffles, in my opinion, taste just as good and are whole heck of a less hassle! I crushed (food processor) up one entire package of reduced fat Oreos and then bought 2 packages of Reeses PB Cups (the ones that come in packages of 6 and are usually on sale for $1). I crushed up the cups and oreos and mixed them together (saving some oreo crumbs for topping later) making pb cup oreo balls. I ended up not needing to refrigerate/freeze them because the balls had a good consistency. We have an old wire with the octagon base that we used to use to dye easter eggs, but now I use it to put the balls into chocolate bark and take back out again. Really useful. Anyways, I bought red chocolate bark and after all the dipping and everything, sprinkled with leftover oreo...they looked really good with a red/black thing going on! : ) Refrigerated them until time to serve---they're better cold!.

I have never made truffles of any kind before and I'm SO glad I tried these! I spend so much money on truffles for myself and for guests and gifts. These truffles are better than any store bought ones I have ever had! They are also so simple to make. They didn't have the Oreo taste I was expecting, so if you aren't a die hard chocoholic you might not like these. However, if you love chocolate and you need an easy recipe, this is your best bet. The best part is, they are easy to make, inexpensive to make, very delicious and they make an absolutely elegant treat. Perfect for parties or guests! Thank you so much for the wonderful recipe!

text:
I made these for a party and they went fast!!!!  I did use some of the suggestions: put them in the freezer about 15 minutes before dipping them in chocolate, I used 2 forks to dip in the chocolate (I dropped the ball in and then used the forks to roll them around and pick them up and out), I used wax paper to keep them on). This turned out great!!!!!!  My friends would like me to put cherries in the middle...didn't know if that would work!  I will have to give it a try!  I also used semi-sweet chocolate chips instead of bakers chocolate, it is cheaper!

These were easy and very good but extremely rich. I have a major sweet tooth and could barely finish one of these. I made them as a Christmas gift for the employees of my local post office and they disappeared fast. One change I would make- 9 cookies for the crumb topping is way too much. text:
Made these today to put in our Christmas Baskets. They turned out wonderful! The first batch, I made with the candy cane oreos(mint flavor wasn't strong, making me wish I'd added peppermint extract to the mix). Second batch, I made with peanut butter filled oreos, and added instant coffee for a mocha flavored truffle. These were everyone's favorite! I coated all the truffles with semi-sweet chocolate, and topped with a varaition of crushed peppermints, coconut, drizzled white chocolate and shaved white chocolate mixed with shimmery red & green sprinkles. I did freeze the truffle mixture before coating with chocolate. I will certainly make again! Thanks for sharing. **Update** I froze the truffles, thawing a few hours before serving at a dinner party...they were even better than before! And the mint flavor from the candy cane oreos was perfect...no need to add extra flavor. The guests loved these truffles! Gave out the recipe several times over:)

text:
These were good but VERY rich. VERY chocolatey! They were easy too, I found that chilling the oreo mixture for about an hour makes it much easier to roll in the melted chocolate. I melted the chocolate in a small slow cooker, this worked great! I skipped the extra step of topping with oreos (completely unnecessary) and put them in small cupcake liners so they looked nice :)  I will make these again, but only when I want a very rich and filling dessert!

Great, but the chocolate is a pain. After trial and error; I melted two bakers blocks in microwave for 60 sec, stirred, then placed my chilled oreo drops in the bowl with the chocolate and rolled them around with a spoon in the chocolate until covered, then placed them back on the cookie sheet.

text:
I made these for a Thanksgiving, and got GREAT reviews! People absolutely loved these!   However, I found that crushing 9 cookies was a little too much for the garnish. I think 5 cookies for garnish would be enough. Also, I scooped the balls with a tablespoon, and found that they became a little too bulky. 3/4 tbsp or 1/2 tbsp would probably be a better size for guests to nibble on. All in all, it was a great recipe, and should be a big hit at any party!

These are so easy and come out so good its hard to believe they are homemade. text:
I made mine wiht mint Oreos. Can't believe that two simple ingredients could result in such a creamy truffle filling! They disappeared before I could try one (sniff, sniff) but my guests RAVED! Make sure to chill the filling well before shaping. It's very soft otherwise. Also, dipping the frozen balls into chocolate makes them easier to handle, but I found that the chocolate shell cracked as the truffles defrosted. Might be something I did wrong, as no one else seems to have had that problem. Anyway, I'm looking forward to trying them again using other flavors.

Display Name:
Blackcat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This got rave reviews at bunko - everyone asked for the recipe.  A few tips - I used a pastry blender to blend the cream cheese and crumbs, and that worked really well.  I let the blended mixture sit in the freezer for about an hour.  Then I rolled the balls and let them sit in the freezer for several hours.  I used almond bark which melted easily in the microwave.  Then I placed a few balls at a time in the melted chocolate and lifted them out with a slotted spoon.  The balls held together well because they were frozen, and the slotted spoon worked well in removing excess chocolate.

text:
AMAZING!! Oddly, I could swear these got better every day and are best 24 hours after made.  Suggestions: Either mash the cream cheese and Oreos together using utensils (rather than hands which will warm the mix too much) or make sure you refridgerate the mix before attempting to make the balls. This will ensure you actually get pretty, round truffles.   Next time, I am going to to try to use milk chocolate. Semi-sweet chocolate was great but I like milk and heard that you can easily substitute the Baker's for two packages of your favorite chocolate chips)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM YUM YUM! Crowd pleaser every time!  I've made a few spin offs using different cookies as well. The Mint Oreo Truffles are so good, but when making remember to only use 3/4 pkg of cream cheese, otherwise your dough will be very greasy.  The Nutter Butter truffles are really good, but very peanut buttery. I've also made what I like to call a "Snickerdoodle Truffle" using a package of Vienna Finger cookies, 3/4 pkg of cream cheese, and a few shakes of cinnamon.  Then coated them in white chocolate.  These are my favorite by far!
