city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the people that had problems either whipped their cream cheese or used double stuffed oreos. DO NOT DO EITHER OF THESE. The object is a dense truffle no air needs beat in there. And, the double stuff just adds a wet element. The only other thing I can think of is to crumb your cookies in the food processor until it starts to clump together. The filling makes this possible and if you add the cream cheese at that stage you'll end up with a wonderful dough.   I used nutter butter and mint chocolate oreos. Definately the nutter butter as my fave. It trumps buckeyes and I'll use this recipe instead. Can't wait to try this with other cookies.

text:
These were delicious. When I started to roll them in chocolate, I found that it was pretty much impossible to do, so I came on here and read some reviews and found that I should chill the balls before trying to dip them. That worked great. Still, though, it was very difficult. The chocolate was way too thick and after a while I ended up wrist deep in chocolate just smearing it on the little cream balls. It was very very messy, but it worked, and the finished product was amazing. I think they're more mini-chocolate cheesecake balls than truffles, but no matter, everyone loved them. I also made the oreos from scratch and didn't add any cream filling to the cookies, and that worked just fine.

The only reason I am giving this recipe a 2 is because my husband and his friend said they tasted good.

text:
Very easy and very rich.  I made these as part of a "thank you" treat bag that I handed out to a group at church, and this was definitely the most complimented item out of everything I made.  I used a 1/2 inch cookie scoop to make the balls, froze them for about an hour, then rolled them with my hands to smooth out the rough edges before dipping in the chocolate.  Drizzling with melted white chocolate makes them look fancier - everyone thought these were really complicated until I told them there are only 3 ingredients!  That's my kind of recipe!

I made these but did my own tweeking. I put 1/2 tsp of almond flavoring and used the large package of milk chocolate chips.  Then I got melted some white chocolate and put it in a ziploc bag. cut the tip and drizzled it over the top.  Teachers LOVED these.  I will be making these every  year as christmas gifts for teachers (I had 12 teachers).  I made two batches of these. By the way, I found if rolled them into balls and froze them instead of putting them into the fridge, it was alot easier dipping them in chocolate with toothpicks!  Messy but worth every minute!!!!!

I did not save any crumbs for the tops, instead I dipped them in the chocolate and then melted some white chips and put them into a sip lock bag, snipped off the end and drizzled the truffles-beautiful and tasty!  I will make these again!

text:
For ease and short ingredient list, this recipe is excellent. My friends are all raving about my 'melt in your mouth' truffles. I only needed about 1 box + 2 squares of semi-sweet chocolate per batch (important to note if you're multiplying the recipe - of course you can always dip extra oreos, pretzels, fruit...have an all out fondue party). And definately freeze 20 min or so between rolling and dipping and again before rolling in extra oreo or they will lose shape. You can add peppermint extract to the chocolate for a twist.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
AWESOME!
Tips:
-Use a cookie scoop so they're all the same size.
-Use different flavors of oreos. I love using berry or mint.
-To add even more flavor options, add a couple tablespoons of coffee syrup flavoring (like raspberry, creme de menthe, or vanilla)
-These don't have to STAY in the fridge for a party. They can be out for a little bit and it won't hurt them. I wouldn't go over an hour or so though.
-Use candy coating for a final "fancy" outside.
-Use sprinkles instead of cookie crumbs on top. Or better yet, use a seasonal sprinkle for a festive look!!!

None
text:
This recipe tastes good but is pretty awful to make. I spent a ton of time waiting for things to be the right temperature. First, softening the cream cheese. Then I froze the oreo/cream cheese balls with toothpicks per other reviews to make dipping it in the chocolate easier. They had to be REALLY frozen for the dipping to go well. If they were still soft at all, they would fall apart while i was doing the chocolate part. Then I stuck them in the freezer again after they were coated in chocolate for a few minutes.
Again, tastes really good, but isn't as easy as the recipe seems, and with all the added wait time, it took way longer than 1.5 hours.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-11-17T08:54:22.173
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
14559004
Display Name:
ivyliv1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

1
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1681807.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making all sorts of dessert recipes to sell at my mother's business as a way to make some money for college, and let me just say these were a hit! And sooo easy to make! I read some of the other reviews and blended the Oreos in my ninja and then, after they were crumbs, added in a block of cream cheese. I didn't use Philadelphia, just the Great Value kind, and it worked perfectly. I left my dough in the blender cup and stuck it in the fridge for about 30 minutes before I rolled it into balls. I think 10 minutes would have done the trick, but I was icing cookies so it had to wait. Once I rolled them into balls (I made 23 large balls) I stuck them into the freezer and started crushing the 9 Oreos in a ziplock bag. A spatula and a little anger did the trick of getting everything crumbly. Then I melted the chocolate, which took much longer to get nice and creamy than the instructions said. I used two spoons and put two balls into the bowl at the same time. Rolled them around in the chocolate until they were covered and then dropped them on a parchment-lined baking sheet. My little helper sprinkled the crushed up Oreos on top while the chocolate was setting and then we popped them in the freezer overnight. Just tried one this morning and they are DELICIOUS. So rich. They are probably a heart attack in your mouth but 2 hours later I'm sold out!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are awesome, and rich. So you can't eat too many at once. Same as others, I did add about a tablespoon of Crisco to the semi-sweet chocolate while melting. Something I did totally different was I heated the Oreo cookies and cream cheese (after putting Oreos through the food processor) and they blended together very easily. They stuck together in the balls very well. I went ahead and placed them in the fridge as I was dipping them and only took a few out at a time to dip in the chocolate. I had absolutely no problems with them crumbling or falling apart. 
Although, just know that it makes for a soft center in the truffles. So, if you're looking for crunch, this may not be the way to go, but you definitely still taste the Oreo.

userID:
11462166
Display Name:
southernpeachcobbler
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy cow! 
After reading reviews I thought I'd say...
It takes a while to crush a whole bag of Oreos at once. Plan on 15 minutes. My friend tells me to use a food processor.
Using double stuff Oreos is a lot stickier when you crush them-but it can be done and tastes great. 
The other Oreo flavors work great too. My favorite is mint!!
Definitely chill after you roll the cookie/cream cheesy goodness together. 
The truffles Do NOT get gooey or melty if you leave them out of the fridge. 
Chocolaty outside coating can be messy. Melt on your hands and not in your mouth if you handle it too long (children). Have bibs ready. 
I had a hard time making the balls small enough (1 inch) to get 40 something servings. I had half that many servings. Think about doing multiple variety of cookies and make lots!

I make buckeyes every year another cookie that needs dipped in chocolate. I typically use a shish kabob skew with a small ring on the end. Much easier to drain the excess chocolate off the cookie. text:
I have made this with both oreo and nutter butter cookies and it is fantastic! Like other users, I refrigerate the cookie mixture for an hour before coating in chocolate. I also do not put the cookie crumb topping. I found the easiest way to work with the dipping chocolate is to melt half of the chocolate in the microwave for about a minute and a half and to use a slotted spoon and regular spoon to coat. Using half of the chocolate at a time seems to work well. I did have a more crumbly truffle with the nutter butters, but I think I did not crush it enough as I used the plastic bag and rolling pin method. While it was not as creamy as my oreo, it still came out fantastic! A little time consuming to make, but totally worth it. The truffles are very rich, and I have been asked to make them for other parties, with someone even offering to pay me to make them for their kid's birthday party. Very good and easy recipe... Makes me look like I know what I'm doing :)

I love love love these truffles, but the only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because they're too greasy if making as directed above. I use a whole package of oreos plus another 15 or so. text:
So delicious! My boss had his wife make these for us around Christmas and everyone loved them so I had to try them myself. So simple and so good.  I found the easiest way to make these is crush the Oreos in a plastic bag then add the cream cheese right into the bag and just squeeze it all up until its well mixed.  Then just turn the bag inside out and dump it into a bowl and roll it into little balls.  Make sure the chocolate is nice and hot so that it goes on smooth when you roll the balls in it.  Keeps really well in the fridge, my husband and I ate these right up!

text:
Made three flavors, the oreo as described, one with vanilla wafers as the cookies and some powdered sugar, and one with crushed andes mints and some chocolate flavored cereal to help with thickening the texture.  Used two plastic forks for dipping and kept the chocolate on the stove in bowls over simmering water.  Blended all in the food processor and chilled the mix before even rolling.  Then froze prior to dipping.  ** Only mistake was putting them on a wire rack to dry.  Too hard to get off! should use wax paper **  Placed them in little shiny candy cups.  The white and milk chocolate made them look like I had made several varietys.  you can check pic.

country:

text:
I LOVED these!!! I bought a chocolate melting pot (escentially a mini crock pot) and melted the chocolate in the microwave and then poured it in the crockpot so that it stayed melted until I was done. I then used a disher, slotted spoon, and a regular teaspoon. I used the disher to scoop out some of the mixture and then released it onto the slotted spoon. Then I used the teaspoon to pour heaps of chocolate on top of the truffle. Then I beat the splotted spoon onto the crockpot so that the chocolate settled down to the bottom, through the slots in the spoon and back into the pot. I then used my teaspoon to scoop the truffle off and slide it onto wax paper. I had no problems at all and never had to touch the truffle until I was ready to eat it. I did chill the balls first in the fridge for about 30 minutes.

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe for years and was glad to see a very similiar version here. The small differences are just personal choices, but this is a GREAT recipe. Definitely freeze the truffle balls for at least an hour before covering in chocolate, it makes it so much easier. (I often will make them and freeze overnight and finish the next day). I have made variations of this and it is always a major delight. It seems to work better to only melt a portion of the chocolate to cover at a time, that way it stays smooth and remains the perfect consistency. I used Ghiradelli chocolate instead of Bakers and usually mix part milk chocolate and part semi sweet. Keep chilled until ready to serve. You'll make lots of people happy with this treat.

text:
This is a very basic recipe for oreo truffles. It's good but we found we liked the vanilla almond bark for dipping and then drizzled with melted semi-sweet chocolate chips. I also weigh the oreos before making them crumbs to a full 18 oz. which is what the oreos used to weigh before it went to 15.5 oz. They come out perfect but they have to be refrigerated. My family likes them right out of the freezer. They never get real hard and they keep very fresh in a ziplock freezer bag. I've seen them done with yellow, green and chocolate bark on lollipop sticks and drizzled with white chocolate for a baby shower. They were absolutely adorable! Have fun with them!!

I've been making this recipe for years now, though no one quite knows what it is. You can also press the mixture into a square plastic-wrap lined pan and let it set over night in the fridge before cutting into squares or rectangles. I like squares, dip them in dark chocolate spiced with a hint of peppermint flavor. Then using a decorator's piping bag you can make white chocolate ribbons on each piece for a fancy designer look.

text:
I made these for my daughter's birthday party. They were a huge hit and the girls would give it 5 stars. I used semi-sweet chocolate to coat - and I personally think almond bark or white chocolate would make them even better. The semi-sweet chocolate made the truffles very rich and delicious. I took the other advice and froze the truffles for a couple of hours before coating, and only melted enough chocolate to keep it smooth and easy to use when coating and melted more as needed. It was easy and not nearly as time consuming as I thought it would be. Would definitely make again!!

text:
I did not have high hopes for these but I thought: oreos, cream cheese, what could go  wrong? 

So I decided to make them for a housewarming party that I was hosting... Although I almost broke a blender (my bad), I finally succeeded to make them. They are surprisingly easy. 

After a while in the fridge, I gave it a go with my boyfriend. They are incredible!!! Amazing! Perfect! I cannot find the words. Incredibly creamy and tasty would probably work. 

I served them to the party and it was a huge hit! And a lot of the people invited were people working with my boyfriend at Ladure which is a French pastry restaurant. Even the chef, who makes incredible food could not believe it! People were joking around that I should become a pastry chef!

Highly, highly recommend them, they are just gorgeous and a real crowd pleaser

text:
I've been making these for years. (Funny my original recipe calls for 20 oz. pkg, but the pkg sizes keep decreasing)  I don't reserve any of the cookie crumbs, but mix it all w/ the cream cheese.  After making the balls, I refrigerate for an hour before dipping in the chocolate.  I use chocolate discs from the candy store or other quick hardening chocolate coating and melt the chocolate in a double boiler to prevent over heating.  Plus it keeps the chocolate hot while dipping.

These are great, I've made them for christmas and party functions.  I find using a small cookie scoop rather than rolling them by hand works best. text:
I made these ahead of time for a Christmas party and they were so good the kids ate them all before it started. They were so easy to make, I had them remake the batch before the company showed up. After mixing the cookies and cheese, we place in the fridge so it was easier to roll then placed the rolls in the freezer so it was easier to dip. The smaller the ball the more pop-able they are. We then tried multiple variations such as mint, pb and strawberry oreos, white/dark chocolate dipping and they were all fabulous.

text:
Yummy and easy!  I used 32 reduced fat Oreos ( I didn't have a whole package) and reduced fat cream cheese.  Tasted great!  Instead of topping coated truffles with remaining Oreo crumbs, I just put sprinkles on top.  I also used vanilla and chocolate almond bark to coat the truffles.  Use a fork to dip them and tap the fork on the side of the bowl once coated.  It helps get any remaining chocolate off.  Enjoy!

text:
I tried a similiar recipe to this one i.e.  finely crushing one pkg of Oreo Cookies, removing 1 tbsps of the crumbs and setting  aside.  Mix the cream cheese & remaining crumbs until well blended.  I used an electric mixer.  Shape into 42 balls.  Refrigerate 30 mins.

Melt choclate squares as directed on package.    Then follow #2 & 3 as stated in this recipe.
 
These Truffles call for a sweet tooth as they are very rich.  I recently served these Truffles at a friend's birthday gathering and they were a huge hit with all the chocolate lovers.

userID:
3881032
Display Name:
Lori

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am usually horrible at melting chocolate, but this time I melted semi-sweet chips in a double boiler with about a tbsp of vegetable oil.  The oil made the chocolate smoother, and it stayed hot and melted longer for dipping the oreo balls.  I even had more than enough time to transfer the melted chocolate to a smaller bowl so that dipping would be easier.  Also, I used a fork/spoon combo when dipping.  I put the balls in the chocolate, covered them using a spoon, lifted them with a spoon, and transferred them to the sheet with a fork to avoid a puddle of chocolate from the spoon.  I think next time I may even transfer them to a wire cooling rack with a cookie sheet underneath to catch any chocolate drippings.  I did have too much melted chocolate and too much leftover cookie for the garnish.  I would recommend only using a 12 ounce bag of chocolate and maybe crushing only 4-6 cookies for the garnish.  We have yet to eat these as they are still cooling, but we are very anxious - how could they be bad?!

text:
I made 5 desserts for friends, and this was the overwhelming favorite.  So I made a second batch.  a few days later.  The second time I added 2 Tbs crisco to the chocolate (I used choc chips) and that made the coating SO MUCH EASIER and prettier.  I did have to make more of the coating than the recipe calls for (both times).  I used a slotted spoon and regular spoon like recommended.  The first time I used my medium size OXO cookie scoop and only got about 20 balls - they were too big.  The second time I used the medium scoop then divided those in half to get about 40 balls.  These were the perfect size.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy to make. I didn't need to put the cookie and cream cheese mix in the fridge. I just mixed very well and made 1 inch balls. I then melted my chocolate. I used chocolate chips in a "double boiler" (a normal sized pot with boiling water with a smaller pot in the large pot). I slowly melted the chocolate. While it was melting I added some butter to thin out the chocolate to make it easy to dip and it gives the chocolate a nice shine when hard. To dip the balls without having them fall apart I used 2 forks on either side of the ball and then dipped away. With using the forks the extra chocolate drains off the ball.

text:
These are great. This time I used a package of Cool Mint Creme Oreos for one batch of them. After I had the dough mixed together it was very very sticky...not thick enough. I checked the package and sure enough, the cool mint oreos only have 30 oreos in the package compared to 39 in regular Oreos so you will need to adjust your measurements for the oreos. I think they are going to turn out okay but the dough was not quite the right consistency.

text:
I agree with the reviewers about how easy this recipe was. I did use a fork to roll the balls in. I found that the toothpick didn't work and two forks were way too cumbersome to work with. I do think next time I make these, I will use bark vs. the chocolate. The chocolate did thicken up towards the end and became slightly more difficult to work with. I also think though that bark looks prettier and smoother than the chocolate looks.

These are amazing! A big hit with the coworkers. A lot of people seem to have problems with the balls falling apart. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome....they're so fun and easy to make if you follow a few simple rules. First use a food processor if you have one to crush the oreo's and mix in the cream cheese. Also make sure you stick the balls in the freezer for 20 minutes or so before dipping in chocolate. This will make life a lot easier when dipping. I dip in batches too, that way the others don't get all gooey while sitting out waiting. Third when you dip the balls don't use toothpicks! I tried one like this just to see how it would work....total failure! Use spoons or forks...this will make life a lot easier! Delicious! Made these for Thanksgiving and they were a BIG hit!!!!

text:
Excellent recipe. Here are some changes.  Form the ball.  Make a depression in the center and put a red cherry.  Press dough around cherry.  Freeze.  Don't use a tooth pick to dip your oreo balls.  Use a wooden scewer, it is thicker and works sooo well.  Sprinkle with favorite topping or refreeze and later drizzle with a contrasting color chocolate.

country:
None
text:
I made the truffles into mini footballs for a tailgating party. Instead of rolling the oreo mixture into perfectly round balls, I rolled them into the shape of a football. I would use milk chocolate next time to dip and cover. The semi-sweet was a little to bitter for my taste. Plus, kids usually go for milk over semi. After they've been dipped and have chilled for a bit in the fridge, use a toothpick dipped into melted white chocolate to draw or drizzle on white lines for laces. They turned out really cute and were a hit at the party.

text:
Great recipe with a ton of flexibility.  I first experienced these at a party where someone made them with mint-filled Oreos - decadent!  I substituted choc & white choc almond bark for the baking chocolate.  Use a food processor for easy prep - I dumped whole cookies and chunks of cream cheese and it mixed up perfectly.  Roll the balls and refrigerate for atleast 1 hour, then dip into melted bar using toothpicks.  Easy and elegant.  Everyone thought they were store-bought!

47
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Incredibly easy and delicious (considering the ingredients). I always freeze the oreo/cream cheese balls for an hour before coating to make them easier to handle and don't bother with the toothpick. Use a water bath to keep the baker's chocolate melted while coating. The chocolate coating will harden fairly quickly when the balls are frozen. I've tried topping with crushed oreo, toasted and crushed walnuts, and toasted and crushed pecans. Pecans were my favorite.

text:
So easy and delicious! Here is the trick to making the mixing and shaping part Super simple: use food preparation gloves! Initially I was frustrated trying to mix the crumbs and cream cheese with a spoon, so I just put on the gloves, mixed it with my hands, and then shaped them by hand as well. SO easy! These are very rich so I made mine a bit smaller (about tsp. size) and was able to get 70 out of one complete package of mint Oreos and 8oz of cream cheese.  Easy, delicious crowd pleasers :)

text:
I recently made these for the first time.  As it was my first time attempting to make truffles, I followed the recipe just as it said.  the only difference is that I used semi sweet chocolate chips instead of the Bakers chocolate.  While they were easy, the most time consuming part was dipping them in chocolate.  I melted  my chips in a double boiler.  I froze the filling before coating in chocolate and I had absolutely no issues with it.  They tasted sooo fantastic! Everyone that I have had try them has said the same thing.  Very sweet   but oh so good!!

text:
Wow, these are yummy!  I rolled the oreo and cream cheese mixture into balls and then refrigerated as others had suggested.  This really helped when it was time to coat them in the melted chocolate. I sprinkled each one with red, white and blue jimmy sprinkles before the chocolate set for 4th of July. These are delicious, but I think I will try Baker's milk chocolate next time instead of the semi-sweet.  Just a personal taste thing.

country:
None
text:
These were SOOOO easy to make.  The part that took the longest was rolling the truffles into balls.  But it was worth it.  I definitely recomend chilling the truffle balls before dipping them in the chocolate.  I didn't have any problems with them breaking.  I made a second or third batch with PB oreos and Mint oreos.  The PB ones I also substituted about 1/3 of the cream cheese with peanut buttter and added a little but of peanut butter to the melted chocolate.  I sprinkled chopped peanuts on the top which looked nice.  The mint ones I added a little peppermint extract to the truffle and to the chocolate and crushed candy canes to sprinkle on top.  Soo yummy and soo easy.  I will definitely make these again.  :)

text:
Delicious. Let the balls cool off before dipping in chocolate. Followed with a spoonful of oreo crumbs, coconut or skor candy bits on top. Was much easier having extra hands (my 6 & 4 year old daughters) to add the extra bits. Try not to make them too big...it's a very rich and filling treat. But also extremely addictive! I found them much better once cooled or directly from the freezer. Thank You! I'd like to say I'll make them again but they are dangerously delicious.

text:
These little tasty morsels are heaven in your mouth!  I made these instead of Christmas cookies and everyone LOVED them.  I dipped them in white chocolate instead of the Semi-Sweet, and then drizzled milk chocolate over the top of them.  I also refrigerated them after I mixed the oreo crumbs and cream cheese for a few hours.  Otherwise they crumble.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These get 5 stars for versatility and simplicity.  They took me less time to make than regular chocolate chip cookies.  I has some Andes mints on hand, so I replaced about 1/3 of the baking chocolate with those to give the truffles a nice peppermint flavor.  Other chocolates could be used, for dipping or drizzling.  In addition, flavored cream cheese (think strawberry cream cheese) could be substituted with great results. To "dip," I simply rolled the balls in the melted chocolate with a fork, scooped them up, and shook them a little to release excess.

DELICIOUS!! These are what oreos should taste like!  They are a bit dangerous to have in the house, though, since they are just the perfect 2-bite size.  I did omit the chocolate on the outside, so I guess technically they are not truffles, but I just rolled them into balls, refrigerated them and then rolled them in sugar.  They look pretty with the white sugar on them and it was SUPER easy with no chocolate mess!

text:
I've been making these for years!!  I sometimes use the Mint Oreos for a change.  Since they have more filling, they are creamier.  Double stuff Oreo's don't work as well- they are too soft!  I always freeze mine before coating them in almond bark so they don't fall apart.  When they cool, I drizzle melted white chocolate over the top for added decoration.  This is one dish, that no matter how much you make, you will never have left-overs!!!  :)

text:
yummy!  i crushed cookies in food processor, then hand mixed w/ the cream chz.  my 3yr old loved rollin the balls.  i let them sit in the fridge about an hour, then  i melted the regular chocolate in the microwave(1min, then stir in 15 sec intervals til almost melted, then stir well) i then just sorta dunked the balls in the chocolate & rolled them around w/ a fork--definitely got a good coatin!! i then sprinkled w/ cookie crumbs piled on top!!my husband at a few b4 they even cooled & raved!!  i really enjoyed them the next day with coffee!!  next time i wanna try nut butter cookies covered w/ white chocolate!!(maybe colored red & green for christmas!!)  thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed a few suggestions from other users - I chilled the rolled up balls in the fridge while I melted the chocolate. By chilling the balls, it made them less crumbly and easier to coat the chocolate on. I used two spoons to roll and coat the melted chocolate onto the ball. I rolled the ball between the two spoons and let the excess chocolate drip off. One thing I wish I did was have more patience letting the excess chocolate drip off... using slatted spoons helps. If you don't let the excess chocolate drip off, you will have balls with pools of chocolate attached to them when they are done hardening (not as appealing). Other than that.. it was really easy to make and delicious.

None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe, so easy to make and my kids had so much fun helping me. Just a quick tip: after mixing cookies with cream cheese put the mixture on the parchment paper and in the freezer for a few minutes, roll it into the little balls and put it back into the freezer, take a few at a time and dip in chocolate (we mixed almond bark with semi sweet), that way the balls don't fall apart and we used a fork, spoon and a toothpick (to wipe extra chocolate when the oreo ball was on the fork).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fun treats to make with the kids. Always a hit! Highly recommend refrigerating Oreo balls before dipping in chocolate; otherwise they soften too much and disintegrate as they warm up. I use a large knitter's stitch holder (looks like an old fashioned diaper pin) to dip the Oreo balls into the warm chocolate. Simply bent the clip to a 90-degree angle, which allows me to rest the Oreo ball on it while I dip. Then I use the straight "arm" of the stitch holder like tongs. Works like a charm and allows me to use just the right amount of chocolate to coat the Oreo balls!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe and I make these all the time for parties because they're yummy, easy, and everybody loves them! I've played around with different flavors too; I've used nutter butters instead of oreos and covered in dark chocolate, i've also used mint oreos and covered in white chocolate both are amazing but I gotta say the original is my favorite. It is super difficult to get the chocolate to stick to the balls, whether you cool them or not. I don't recommend the toothpick it makes them fall apart and creates a mess! First I add a little cream with the chocolate while melting, not a lot, but it makes the melted chocolate runnier. Then I use two spoons, one for the ball and one to pour the chocolate over then I just toss the ball between the two. When I run out of time I just roll the balls in powder cocoa and it does the trick! Hope this helps!

text:
EVERYONE, you must try to make tea truffles out of these. They are a HIT! I infused loose leaf Jasmine tea in one small batch, blueberry rooibos tea in another batch, and earl grey tea in another batch. Continue making them with the same prodcedure and you get the tea taste. Also, sprinkle the tea leaves on top!m They're
amazing desserts! Super easy and super delicious. I processed the a whole pack of oreos in a food processor to make the job easier compared to the rolling pin. I dipped half of my batch with white and other half dark chocolate.   The  melting chocolate I used are Candy Melts from Michaels Arts and Crafts store. Since I don't have a double-broiler, I simply microwaved them and they were great to work with.  I also freezed them for an hour and used toothpicks to dip them.

text:
I have been using this recipe for years now and everyone raves about them.  The favorite in my family is the mint oreo version.  If you use the mint or any other kind of cookie with more filling in the middle you can cut back on the cream cheese to make the "dough" easier to work with.

text:
These are delicious and always please the masses. I make them fairly small, almost bite sized because they are very sweet. I chill the balls before dipping them in chocolate and always find it's best to use a slotted spoon or small tongs to do the dipping. I also always use white chocolate since it makes them look and taste better (in my opinion). So easy and so delicious! I recommend them for events or gifts as everyone seems to like them and I never come back with any left.

text:
Yum! I've made these over and over and always get rave reviews...and everyone thinks I accomplished something really difficult! A little time-consuming, but easy. Have never used the food processor, crush the oreos in a plastic bag and the cream cheese will soften any bigger chunks and result in a uniform truffle. I use chocolate almond bark exclusively now and use the fork method to dip the truffles. (I agree with chilling the rolled balls first!) I like to place the finished truffles in mini muffin cups--the balls themselves aren't very attractive, not that it's ever been a deterrent!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wish I could rate these 4.5 stars, because that would be more accurate. The truffles were a total "5" for taste and appearance, however were soft and difficult to work with. I ended up having to stick them in the freezer before dipping them in chocolate. Then the opposing temperatures caused the truffle to ooze out any cracks in the chocolate. Other than that, I didn't have a problem. Also, I found that I needed to use all of the oreos that the recipe called for for the truffles. Hand beating was not nearly as effective as using the countertop mixer. After all of these adjustments, the recipe is pretty much perfect and got rave reviews from the 20 or so people who received them for Christmas from me! I served them in little tins with the "Peanut Butter Truffles" and "Easy Decandent Truffles" from this site. The Oreo ones were my favourite. I decorated them by dipping in chocolate and sprinkling with a dusting of Oreo baking crumbs.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These truffles are absolutely DELICIOUS and are so unbelievably simple to make.  This is the second time I've made them in the past couple of weeks and I think I've perfected the process (without changing the recipe). TIP 1: Once the cookies & cream cheese are mixed, REFIGERATE mixture for an hour. TIP 2: Use a Mellon Ball scooper to scoop out onto the waxed paper. TIP 3: REFIGERATE the rolled balls another hour to harden.  This makes it easier to roll in the melted chocolate. TIP 4: Try different chocolates for dipping!!   I dipped some in White chocolate  and some in semi-sweet chocolate; the white-dipped ones were FANTASTIC.  The two flavors really complimented each other!!!  Definitely a keeper of a recipe...

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy, and oh so easy. My six year old loved helping me make these. After crushing the cookies in the food processor, I added the cream cheese directly to the food processor. Chill in the bowl for 30 minutes. ONLY USE REAL CREAM CHEESE!  Used a small cookie scoop to scoop them out, and then chilled again. The rolling in melted chocolate is messy and time consuming, but worth it! I made two batches for Christmas. The first using Peppermint Jo-Jos (Trader Joe's Oreos), melted semi sweet chocolate chips, and then drizzled with melted peppermint kisses. The next batch I made with Chocolate/Vanilla Jo-Jos, and covered in white chocolate, and sprinkled with red, white, and green nonpareils, and they were beautiful! I will make these every Christmas from now on!

text:
I had no problem at all of rolling the crushed Oreo mixture upon refrigerating them for 1 hr but found the process of coating with melted chocolate to be too much a hassle (even using 2 forks as advised by others). The chilled Oreo mixture tasted extremely nice which contradicts to chocolate coating as I can't find good chocolate at our local store last night. I had to give away the 2 boxes of finished truffles to workers this morning as we really didn't enjoy eating any of it. Guess I won't be making it anymore judging from the hassle of making, rolling and coating, coupled with washing with the extremely-difficult-to-get-off hardened chocolate over my bowls and forks, etc as well as time and effort spent.

Nick-Shouldhavebeenacook-Craig

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Chocolate filled chocolate, how can you go wrong! These are by far my most favorite thing to make in my tiny overworked kitchen. The most important thing to remember though, is that while this will always taste exquisite, the presentation matters most in truffles.  Drizzle some contrasting colors over the top, white on dark... I like to mix it up, with a sweet chocolate coating and drizzled in white and dark chocolate. A few other changes that i HIGHLY recommend are to use half Oreo's and half Girl-scout thin mints. you get an amazing mint flavor that will make your mouth water. I also like to add the Oreo dusting to the drizzle, not the main coating.  For anyone wondering. A great trick to melting chocolate without a double boiler, is the microwave! chop your chocolate up to pea sized and microwave for 30 seconds at 50% power. do this a couple of times while stiring to melt perfectly. when the chocolate is almost melted, just stir it and let the chocolate melt itself. I prefer a ceramic bowl for this cause it dissipates the heat well. french onion soup bowls work great as well.

I have made this recipe several times.  This is a great wedding cookie recipe.  I always drizzle a little white chocolate on each truffle. I have tried with mint oreos and tinted the white chocolate w/ green.  Today I am trying this with the Christmas peppermint  oreos & drizzle w/ pink or red chocolate. country:
None
text:
Best recipe ever! Always the hit of any get together, guaranteed! The options are endless as far as variety and decorating. I, too have struggled with the dipping but I discovered a trick last time I made them. I used 2 fondue forks because I had literally tried everything else and they kept falling apart and looking a mess! I used one to stick in the the balls (after freezing to get as firm as possible!) and I used the other to slide the ball off of the first one onto the wax paper and fix and inconsistent texture on top. They really did work wonders and made the process much easier! My favorite way to decorate is to dip a fork into the opposite chocolate that the ball is dipped in and sling around over the top of the balls- gives them a very fun look.. Any type of sprinkles or colored sugar make them look great too! Can't go wrong with these! Don't worry if yours turn out messy looking at first, they will still taste AMAZING and you will figure out a method that works for you!

text:
These are out-of-this-world good!  And easy!  I followed the recipe to a tee..  and while I began melting the chocolate, I put the truffles in the fridge to chill (for easier dipping later).  I also enjoyed how minimal the ingredients were, and the cleanup was not so bad either.  Just make sure to sprinkle on the topping within a minute of dipping in the chocolate (the chocolate dries fast)!  I used the Oreo crumbs for most, but also added some fresh, chopped bacon to a few (for those chocolate & bacon lovers out there)! :)

text:
Prefer it with white chocolate.  To avoid the mess and inconsistent size I use an ice cube tray as a form.  Put a little melted chocolate in, add a slightly smaller molded lump of cookie mixture and press gently into chocolate.  Cover with more chocolate to form around the creamy center.  Chill and once cold, just pop them out like ice cubes.

This is an awesome easy recipe that tastes awesome with little effort. My son enjoyed crushing the cookies in the ziploc bag. Do freeze the balls for a little while it makes them much easier to work with. I want to try this again with mint oreos. Oh... and if you want a thinner chocolate coating leave your chocolate on a double boiler while dipping. I personally don't like the thick coating that turns out if the chocolate cools too much.

text:
Excellent! I'm horrible in the kitchen, but took the advice of the other reviewers and they came out great! Someone even said "Bakery Quality"! Definitely freeze the dough for a couple of minutes before rolling, then refrigerate before dipping in the chocolate. Only melt 1/3 or 1/2 of the chocolate at a time. I made 3 batches - one with regular oreos, one with mint oreos, and one with peanut butter oreos! I added a drop of vegetable oil to the melted chocolate to give the truffles a nice glaze - Came out beautifully!

TMARS81

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. It turns out delicious every time and it's a good thing it tastes so good because my truffles always come out looking so ugly. I've tried all sorts of different methods for coating these. I always chill the mixture and I've tried toothpicks, 2 spoons, 2 forks, a slotted spoon....none of them work. I still haven't yet found a method that works for me.     I've found that the best way to make the mixture, and this will take you about 10 extra minutes, is to separate the oreos from their stuffing. I usually open the oreo, scrape the stuffing out into the bowl with my cream cheese and toss the oreo into the baggie that I will crush the cookies in. Then I beat the cream cheese and oreo stuffing, then continue beating as I add in my bag of oreo crumbs that I crushed. This makes the mixture so smooth and easy to work with when it's chilled.     I like to top mine with melted white chocolate piped on with a baggie with a hole cut in the corner. It dresses them up some because mine are so ugly that they need all the help they can get. But where it counts - the taste - is GREAT!

Wow....just made these and they are fantastic! I used my food processor to crush the cookies and then added the cream cheese  and blended it together. region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are better than you can imagine.  I use the chocolate almond bark for dipping instead of the semisweet baking chocolate.  Definitely chill the balls before dipping and I have found a fork works best for dipping.  Place the chilled oreo ball on top of the fork and dip.  Do not pierce the oreo ball with the fork.  When you bring the fork out of the chocolate simply tap the fork on the edge of the bowl and the excess chocolate will run back into the bowl.

text:
These are SO DELICIOUS and so easy!!  you can't go wrong with these.  We've used regular oreos, double stuff oreos, blended them til smooth 1 time, the other time we crushed with a rolling pin and there were still some "chunks".  We covered the first batch with melted chocolate, the toher time we didn't even bother!  Any way you have them they are great, and not too over-the-top rich like some truffles can be.  We used a small scoop to portion these out and then froze them for easier handling.  We'll be making these again and again!

I have been making these for a few years. I found the recipe in an issue of Kraft "Food & Family" mag. text:
very good and very easy. I wasn't sure if teh recipe called for removing the cream filling or not, but i was in a hurry and didn't want to. i took the whole package of cookies and broke them up into my mixer and let it have at it for a few minutes. then added the cream cheese and was good to go. 

i would shape the dough into balls then chill, and coat in chocolate.

the two fork technique really does work the best. i thoughth a slotted spoon would work but it tracked chocolate everywhere! i was skpetical that the balls would stay on the fork but the chocolate helps the balls stay on the forks while switching from fork to fork to get rid of excess chocolate.

also these are pretty sweet so smaller balls are better

This is (by far) my favorite sweets recipe. I have made this so many times for the Christmas Season and I continue to have many many requests for it. I agree with putting the truffles in the fridge for about an hour before dipping, and dip fast! Otherwise these guys start to melt. FABULOUS recipe. Can't go wrong.

text:
I LOVED this easy recipe. The inside of the truffle was nice and creamy you can definitely taste the Oreoes inside and out. I used Chocolate almond bark instead of the bakers chocolate because the bakers chocolate doesnt harden as well as the almond bark. Overall this recipe was a hit with the family, everyone loved it!! I'm going to make this again but with different type of Oreos.

text:
I have made these for several years and have also used Nutter Butters, vanilla oreos, and mint oreos. Always turn out yummy! I throw the cookies in the food processor and pulse them to crumbs, then add softened cream cheese and pulse just until blended. I refrigerate then use a cookie scoop and roll in powdered sugar. I often have the kids make these because it is so quick and easy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made my first test batch in preparation for the holidays and brought some to work to share. They were a huge hit! I made half with milk chocolate and half with white chocolate. I used several tips found in other reviewers comments  I chilled the dough in the fridge for about 30 minutes before making the balls. Then I froze the balls on 2 separate baking sheets for an hour before dipping in the chocolate, and took one sheet out at a time for dipping. I added vegetable oil to the chocolate and had no problem with the chocolate getting too thick and the frozen balls didnt fall apart in the chocolate. I tried a couple of methods for dipping  the toothpick method worked well for coating, but I messed up the top of the balls trying to get the toothpick out. When I tried to fill the hole and with chocolate it just made the tops messy looking. The fork and spoon method worked best for me. I am already thinking of varieties for Christmas  mint Oreos with Andes chocolate chip morsel coating, crushed peppermint on top, red/green sprinkles, etc. Easy and excellent!

text:
Just gorgeous. Impressed a lot of people with these, which is great, because they're so simple. My only problem was, it was hard to roll them in the chocolate without them falling apart at times or getting really messy. I solved that by stabbing them with a bamboo skewer, dipping, and then placing on the tray. then drizzled a little extra chocolate on top to cover the hole made by the skewer. Altogether really delicous.

text:
I crushed the Oreos first in a food processor then added the cream cheese and processed until it came together like dough.  I chilled it in the freezer for about 20 minutes, rolled out the balls and freezer them again for 30 minutes.  Only dipped half a batch at a time since they defrost pretty fast.  Overall it came out great for my first attempt!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What's not to like about this recipe?  I even made it kid friendly!  I put the cookies into bags and let my 2-year-old smash it with a rubber mallet.  Then I dropped the cream cheese in the bag and let him squish it around.  Then he helped me roll the mixture into balls and put in on a cookie sheet.  The only thing he couldn't help with was the chocolate dipping.  They were a hit at the party I took them to, although the elder crowd did mention they were a little too sweet and rich.  One note, though:  let these sit in the fridge for a while, probably overnight.  That gives the cream cheese time to soften the cookie crumbs, and makes them much more truffle-like.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-12-19T19:17:20.183
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
7537385
Display Name:
Alice =^..^=
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1059942.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe & it really isn't difficult (like some people said in other reviews)it just takes a little patience & time & a few tweaks!I did use less cream cheese because I read so many reviews saying it was too moist so I used all of the cream cheese block except about 1/4 cup.I used semi-sweet chips & made my own doubleboiler by filling a large pot halfway with water & keeping it on low heat & placing a small pot inside (Be careful to NOT let water get in your chocolate-it will ruin it!) & melted the chips that way. It was pretty thick so I added about 1 tbsp of crisco to thin it out. Once you roll the balls of the oreo-cream cheese mixture, put them in the FREEZER for at least 20 minutes. Then use a toothpick to pick them up & do a quick dip in the chocolate & then tap the toothpick on the side of the pan about 30 times or until it stops drizzling. Then, to put the truffle on the wax paper carefully shake it off the toothpick (don't use you're fingers or a fork or else it will make it look ugly!) & it will evenutally fall off. You can fill the little toothpick hole by dipping the toothpick in the chocolate and dabbing it on the hole and it gives it a pretty swirly top on the truffle (see my pic)! Do as many as you can until the balls need to be chilled again. If they get too warm they will start to crumble when you are trying to dip them so keep them chilled. When you give them as a gift just tell people to keep them refridgerated. They are absolutely divine!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loves these but I found that just 36 cookies is too sticky so I use 40 cookies and have about half a pack of cookies left for later of if I'm making another batch ( I always buy two packs just in case). The extra 4 cookies makes it less sticky and easy to role without chilling. I also found that 9 cookies is too much extra to cover that balls with, 4-5 is plenty and I make about sixty smaller ones instead of the larger one inch. Sprinkles also make these really pretty and still just as amazingly tasty.

None
country:
None
text:
OMG, these are ungodly good!  A few suggestions:  I ended up crushing them in a ziploc with a rolling pin--quick and easy.  I used a small ice-cream style scoop which was the perfect size for the balls & made a flat bottom.  Froze the balls for about 45 minutes, then dropped them in the chocolate, rolled them around and scooped them with a slotted spoon so that the flat bottom was down, tapped it a few times to get the drips off and pushed back onto the cookie sheet & froze again.  I will leave them in the freezer until ready to serve.  They can sit out awhile, but will get soft after some time.  Will try other cookies and coating next time.  Fairly quick, easy and a pretty recipe.  Great to make with younger kids. Or make ahead of time for a party, store in freezer until ready to go.

None
text:
These are delicious! They are very, very sweet so be prepared. I found the dipping is easiest if you have 2 people. Put truffle on a fork and hold over pot with melted chocolate. Have other person spoon chocolate over truffle. Slide truffle off fork with a toothpick onto wax paper. This sounds complicated but it saves a lot of the chocolate and isn't messy.

text:
I know I'm just reiterating what everyone says when I claim that this recipe is great, easy, flexible ingredients-wise, and a huge crowd-pleaser! But I've seen a few reviews stating that the dipping of the balls can be tricky. Just use two forks, not spoons or toothpicks, tap the fork holding the ball a few times in the edge of your mixing bowl, then wipe away any excess from the bottom of that fork with the free one - works every time! And I'm a HUGE klutz.

Wonderful!  These get lots of compliments and you can make them early, freeze for a couple days, then let thaw on the way to gatherings.  Make sure to put the balls in the freezer for about an hour before drying to dip.  This helps the balls stay attached to the toothpick to dip.  These taste good frozen but taste even better cold.

Display Name:
pinknavy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here in Phoenix, our local dollar store has 1lb packages of nutter butter pieces(already ground up cookies).  I used a bag of those and mixed it with the cream cheese. I used other recommendations for using a food processor to incorporate the two together perfectly. I chilled them in the deep freeze while I melted the chocolate(I used almond bark since I keep that on hand). I then used a slotted spoon to dip the truffles.  Instead of using cookie pieces as the outside garnish, I treated it as a regular dessert truffle and gently sifted cocoa powder over the truffles, and set them up in the deep freezer. Hubby is going to LOVE these(his fav candy is Reese's). They are his Valentine's day surprise since he works nights.

text:
Very yummy! As others suggested, I chilled dough for 1 hour before rolling into balls, and then chilled ballls before dipping in almond bark.  It was much easier to work with, but I still had some crumbs fall off into the chocolate.  Luckily the crumb topping disguised the "dirty" chocolate and they were still attractive.

text:
I use Mint OREO cookies instead of the regular flavor, and everyone LOVES them!  I actually crush the oreos into very small pieces, dip the chilled (so much easier when they're chilled) balls in chocolate, and roll them in a bowl of oreo pieces.  Tip: Using a crockpot to melt the chocolate and keep it warm has worked well for me.  We keep them in the freezer for the holidays, and they are always a huge hit!

The recipe, as written didn't work well for me. The "balls" never hardened well. I had to chill the dough before even rolling them. I froze the balls but when they hit the warm chocolate they softened and left oreo behind. It was quite a mess and didn't come out looking anything like all the lovely pictures posted here. I tried the fork trick and that didn't help much. They look awful, but taste good. I wonder if you used the whole package of oreos if it would make the dough stiff enough to make this work? I'm so disappointed!

text:
I just made a batch of these.  They are delicious!  A great thing to make with the kids because of the no baking! They loved mixing everything and making the balls. I did freeze them before and after rolling for about 20 minutes.  Also, I used almond bark instead of chocolate chips as someone suggested.  They seemed to be a bit messy (the cookie crumbs), but other than that great!  I made half of them with white chocolate and the other half with regular chocolate.  I drizzled the leftover chocolate over the top of them after dipping to make them a bit prettier. I do not have a food processor, but it would have been much easier and quicker if I had!

Oct.23,2011 -- I only made half a batch to test for a party. I had refridgerated it for a while before taking it out and boy, once it was on the table ....... gone! I had used white chocolate and I think it made a big difference.  Since these were rich, I think I will make them a tad bit smaller. I also think these balls are better than than cake balls. Update: Dec.28,2011 - Since, I like using white chocolate, you must use a double broiler. Also, take a plastic fork, break out the 2 middle tines and it makes the perfect "dipper"

text:
My daughter made these for a party.  They were VERY easy and just delicious.  She rolled them a little larger and got 36 truffles, however, I would roll them a bit smaller as they are quite rich.  We also used a 12oz. bag of semi-sweet chocolate chips (it was a lit less expensive than the Baker's chocolate) and there was a lot of chocolate left over.  Next time I'd start with half the bag, you can always melt more chocolate.  This recipe is definitely a keeper and we will certainly make them again!

userID:
3002528
Display Name:
Courtney
isPro:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The end result is fantastic, but I found them to be really fussy. 

The bakers chocolate I used didn't solidify like it should have. It just ran into pools. Luckily, I had some gulf wax laying around from our peanut butter balls. I melted 2 ounces into 16 ounces of bakers chocolate. It gave the chocolate a nice glossy sheen and everything started hardening properly. Note: if you've never used this before, you have to work fast on sprinkling the the truffles with crumbs.

We used a toothpick (a new one for every ball so the chocolate doesn't collect and leave huge holes) and that worked out for us as long as it was twisted out immediately after setting it on the wax paper. The fork recommendation left big gouges in the truffles.

I sort of shunned the recipe after all that work and little payoff. They didn't taste great after they set for an hour or so. I put them in the fridge overnight. This morning we tried one and they're definitely better. I would recommend at least 24 hours in the fridge so that they really set up. If you serve them too soon you really taste the cream cheese.
Review:
Rating:
5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/401423.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Incredible!  Super easy to make, super good to eat!  My 7 year old niece came through the dining room, looking for more, exclaiming "those chocolate meatballs are WONDERFUL!"  I didnt have a processor.  We just used a rolling pin and plastic bags.  So we mixed the cream cheese up by hand, and I think literally with our hands by the end of it.  I did chill them off before rolling, and then again before dipping.  I wasn't part of the dipping, but I think my sister ended up using a fork and a slotted spoon.  I used Milk Chocolate chips that I melted in the microwave.  Some of the balls were a little bigger than others but we tried to make them bite size, knowing they were going to be super rich.  I did use Fat-Free cream cheese and they were still excellent!  Will make again next year (and maybe again this year)

text:
Very simple recipe, received nothing but compliments! I mixed everything, chocolate crumbs and cream cheese, in a food processor. Found the mix was a little easier to roll into balls after refrigerating for an hour or so. Just a tip, I ended up putting the balls on the end of a fork and pouring the melted chocolate over them, then sliding it gently off onto parchment paper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/588337.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing.  I used mint oreos - yum!! Instead of the baking chocolate, I used chocolate almond bark at the suggestion of a family member - it worked great.  I chilled the insides in the freezer for a few hours, stuck them each with a toothpick, and dipped them in the almond bark (melted over low-low heat).  I learned that if you leave the toothpicks in and spin them out once they've cooled a bit, the hole you need to cover is much smaller and it didn't fall apart for me. Will be making these again for sure!  Update: made again with Nutter Butters - very good also, but I think I prefer the oreo.

text:
These truffles are excellent and very easy to make. I followed advice from other reviews and used a beater to mix the crumbs and cream cheese together. I then used a one tablespoon cookie scoop to measure out the dough before rolling it into balls. Next into the freezer for one hour before dipping into melted white chocolate chips. Sprinkles on top and voila! The truffles are VERY rich but I still prefer the oreo fudge over these.

Excellent recipe. I did not have any trouble with crumbling. I made sure the cream cheese was very soft and then mixed cream cheese with finely chopped cookies with my hands (after a thorough washing of course:). This allowed me to really combine the ingredients and form into large ball. They sat in fridge while I prepared the dipping chocolate-and perfecto! Sinfully rich!

text:
These are delicious and I don't even like cream cheese. I mix butter with the chocolate morsels till the consistency is a little thinner because it makes it easier to coat. You can either use a small crock pot or you can melt in the microwave for 1 minute, mix, and then 20 second increments. To make dipping easier, I used a big spoon with slits in it, so the extra chocolate drips off & transport the truffle with a tiny spoon to parchment paper.

These are amazingly easy and incredibly yummy and RICH!  I made these for my husband and son who both love oreos. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/235461.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  Good!  Easy to make!  My daughters helped me make the balls and loved it.  Of course they had to try one and make sure that their work was quality :).  Many other reviewers stated that they had problems with the balls falling apart when they were coating them.  I did not have this problem at all.  Just make sure that when you roll the cookie/cream cheese balls, you roll them until they are solid.  I told my daughters it was like playing with playdough.  I used white coating and reserved a small amount.  I colored the reserve coating green for St. Patty's Day and made criss-crosses over the tops.  They looked store quality!  You could use any color if you use the white.  You can also use different sandwich cookies for different flavors.  I'm going to make them in the shape of eggs for Easter!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2010-02-20T10:19:15.467
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4598977
Display Name:
RHess10051
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty easy to make.  Had a little bit of clean-up time, but then again, I'm a messy baker.  I found that using my blender worked (as I do not have a food processor).  I put in about 4 cookies at a time and used the chop and grate settings.  I found that it is important to make sure you follow the directions and have the balls pre-rolled BEFORE you melt the chocolate and start dipping.  I melted 4 oz of the chocolate first (1 package)and dipped 1/2 the batch.  Then, I melted the other 4 oz. of chocolate and dipped the rest of the batch.  This kept the chocolate from hardening too quickly.  Didn't take too long to make, and this was with me entertaining a 1 1/2 year old during the process!!
Review:

5

text:
All I can say is WOW about this recipe. The result is absolutely AMAZING. I could probably type pages of praise about this recipe. I had no idea that with just these three ingredients you could make something that tastes like you would pick up in a gourmet chocolate shop! The inside is so creamy and rich and the coating perfectly compliments it. It doesn't even taste like cookies were used to make them at all!  I let the balls chill overnight to make it easier to dip and I melted my chocolate in a glass bowl over a saucepan of simmering water. With the balls chilled that long, I had absolutely no problem dipping them. So easy, so delicious, I DEFINITELY recommend this recipe to anyone!!!

country:
None
text:
Originally, a friend made these for me and they were delicious. So, although I'm generally inept at baking, I decided to give it a try. Because my local grocery store didn't have precisely what the recipe called for, I made these substitutions: 1) 12 oz. Oreo cookies 2) 8 oz. Nestle semi-sweet chocolate.  Overall, the truffles came out pretty good. VERY RICH. I think I am only capable of eating one before needing to stop for hour for another. I do wish I had used some oil and the slotted spoon idea because dipping the chocolate definitely needed both.  So with this these proportions and making slightly bigger truffles, my friends and I made approximately 25 truffles. Good enough size to individually wrap and hand off as gifts. Overall, though, very very easy to make. The longest time is the cooling, and the most difficult step is properly coating the oreo/cream cheese balls. I would recommend this recipe to others.

text:
these truffles are yummy! it is pretty simple to make, but as a first time baker/new cook, I had no idea how to melt chocolate. So suggest looking that up if you don't know now, cause its trickier then it seems. I burnt my first batch of chocolate. And I suggest using the microwave. To coat the balls, I had a laddle full of chocolate, and used a spoon to roll my chilled balls around. This worked beautifully, and the truffles turned out pretty!

helpfulCount:

userID:
845691
Display Name:
CallieJo
isPro:

23
favoritesCount:
31
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/577802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't know why everyone has had such a hard time with these in the chocolate. First of all you MUST use double stuff Oreos. Put them in the food processor until finely ground. Then throw in 8 oz. package of cream cheese and you might have to stop the processor and stir it around a little to get it to mix well. It will form into a huge glob when it gets well mixed. Then use a teaspoon to make the balls and put on a cookie sheet. Stick a toothpick in the middle and put in the freezer for at least an hour. I use half a package of white almond bark and chocolate almond bark. Only melt one kind at a time so it is nice and melted while you are covering the balls. Follow the directions on the almond bark package to melt. Then dip the chilled balls in the almond bark and place back on the cookie tray to harden. Cover half with white and half with chocolate almond bark. Then melt one more square of each kind of almond bark and drizzle over the tops of the truffles. If the chilled balls start to fall off of the toothpicks while you are trying to dip them then stick them back in the freezer for a few minutes to rechill. SO yummy and such a crowd pleaser.

text:
I made these for a holiday party and they are amazing! I actually made them with fat free cream cheese and reduced fat oreos to make them a little "healthier," and they were DELICIOUS! You would never even know that they were made with the fat free stuff! We had our chocolate fountain running the night of the party so we simply held the balls under the running fountain, which created a nice, smooth coating. I am going to make them again, as per the request of some family and friends, however I am going to use regular Baker's chocolate, so we shall see how it goes using some other user's suggestions for easy dipping!

text:
Personally I LOVED these, but Im a big sweets fan, alot of people thought they were to sweet, even I could only eat 2 or 3 of them. I did exactly how the recipe said, except i didnt have a food processer so i used a blender which is a pain because you can only crush about 5 or 6 at a time. I didnt have a double boiler so i used a saucepan with boiling water with a larger saucepan laid over it. I found the chocolate stiffened fast after about the first half and they were starting to look sloppy, a added a little bit of milk which did wonders!!! They were definitly yummy!

text:
The Best!  I made these for Holiday treats and everyone thought I purchased them.  Tricks: Use a tablespoon to make the oreo balls.  Then put in freezer for at least  1 1/2 hours; this makes it easier to coat the balls in chocolate.  Melt the chocolate in a double boiler and add a small peice of baking wax (this gives a professional gourmet look).  To dip the chocolate use a spoon.  Then place on wax paper.

Thought these were delicious.  I used mint oreos and reduced fat cream cheese and feel that it left the inside a bit "doughy", so next year I may use the regular cream cheese.  I reserved 9 cookies for toppings as the recipe stated, however, I feel that 3 maybe 4 would have been plenty and used the remaining in the mix. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The taste is so awesome! Tastes just like what the pros make. Some hints: 1. Use a food processor. It's SO much easier and the idea of rolling over OREOs in a plastic bag doesn't work. (I tried it, and it was a mess.) 2. Make sure to refrigerate or freeze the dough before and after making balls to keep the balls firm. 3. I rolled the balls in melted chocolate with a spoon and I scooped chcocolate onto the balls with a spoon as well. The fork/toothpick way is just too awkward. 4. You better refrigerate these if you want them to stay good. The cream cheese inside will go bad when exposed to warm temperatures for too long. Overall, I love it!

text:
These are wonderful. I brought some to work today and have never heard such rave reviews. I did read the frustrations from past reviewers on dipping the ball into the chocolate. So, I used a gravy ladle which worked perfect. Spooned a little melted chocolate in the bottom, dropped in a ball, spooned a little chocolate over the top then scooped it out with the spoon. I only chilled the dough in the freezer for maybe 10 minutes and did not have any fall apart. I also used my food processor to crush the oreos and my kitchen aid to mix. They could not have been easier or more perfect.

text:
These were delicious! I ended up putting them in the fridge before dipping them in chocolate (for 2 hours because I had other things I needed to do). I ended up melting my chocolate in a bowl over a pot of boiling water and then just left it on there so the chocolate would stay nice and runny. I dropped the truffle balls into the chocolate, used a fondue fork to swirl them around, and then used 2 fondue forks to pull them out - worked great! I'll definately be making these again!

text:
I've never made candy before but made this with the nutter butter substitution for a contest and won 1st place. Other tips:  1. I used more cream cheese than in the recipe to avoid the crumbliness.    2. I chilled the dough for an hour before dipping.  3. Used almond bark for the chocolate.  4. After the dipped candies had cooled and hardened, I melted butterscotch chips and drizzled in a zig zag pattern across the top, and sprinkled on crushed butterfinger.  Better to do with a helper so you can add it quickly before the butterscotch starts to dry.  5.  I stored it in an airtight container in the fridge for 5 days, then let it "breathe" uncovered in room temp for 6 hrs.

text:
My husband and I made these for the first time last night and they taste great! If you don't have a food processor I recommend taking the filling out of the oreos before crushing them with a rolling pin, and then just add the filling to the mixture. Also, as for dipping them in the chocolate, I found it worked best to stick the balls in the freezer for 15-20 minutes, and then dip them in chocolate using a tooth pick. We tried covering them with chocolate using a spoon as some suggested but it was very messy!!! Next time we make these I will use milk chocolate or even white chocolate. Great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  My husband and son are addicted to these things.  I took them to a party recently and everyone requested the recipe.  Even the pickiest eaters love these.  I actually dip them in white chocolate, though it seems to be harder to work with than milk chocolate.  My experience is that Candi-Quick works the best.  It comes in a microwaveable tray that's quick and easy to use.  I make the balls using a small scoop and refrigerate for a while to firm them up (makes them easier to dip).  I simply plop the ball in the tray of chocolate and spoon the chocolate over the top.  The I lift it out with a fork to allow the excess chocolate to drip off.  Then I place them on a metal baking sheet covered with wax paper.  It will take 2 trays of Candi-Quick to cover all the balls.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Very good and easy to make. Just a tad messy just to warn you. Use a food processor to chop up the cookies into fine pieces, and with a hand held mixer, use this to blend the cream cheese & cookie crumbs. I put the whole mixture into the fridge for an hour at least (overnight if you can, works the best). I use a small cookie scoop to make the balls, and dip with a fork (put ball at the edge of fork) and use a spoon to pour chocolate over it. I also dye the white chocolate red and green during Christmas time. These are a hit and everyone enjoyed them!

Wow!  Just perfection!  I wanted to test these out (& didn't want too many around the house) so I made 1/4 recipe.  I followed the tip of a previous reviewer & broke the two middle tongs off of two plastic forks & used them to dip -great idea!  I dipped them in Wilton's Light Coco candy melts & then drizzled them with some semi-sweet chocolate that I added a little shortening & Wilton's Creme De Menthe candy flavoring to.  After reading reviews, I was worried that these would be a major pain to make but they were surprisingly easy & impressive -especially considering that they are rich & a little goes a long way!

I topped the truffles with orange stripes for Halloween, and you couldn't tell that I hadn't quite figured out the dipping, though. I'll be waiting until I have a food processor for crushing the Oreos before I make these again, but they're wonderful!!

text:
Hmmm....I;d like to give thid recipe 5 stars for taste but 4 stars for being WAY off on the time it takes to do this recipe.  You definately need to chill the cookie mixture for at least an hour before you dip them in melted chocolate.  I also found it helpful to inset a tooth pick into eacg ball before chilling them on a wax paper lined cookie sheet.  This made it much easier to dip the balls in melted chocolate.  I found melting the chocolate on the stove in a steel bowl over hot water made for really smooth chocolate.  Make sure you a tsp. of shortening to the melted chocolate to give it a nice sheen.  You will need to be really careful when taking the toothpick out after dipping the ball in chocolate but trust me, this method works the best!

text:
These are really easy, fun to make and absolutely delicious.  We didn't make them for any occasion, just messing around on a Sat.  I don't have a food processor but I do have a 13yr old son who was more than happy to crush the cookies in a ziploc bag & that method worked really well.  I also used the Baker's baking chocolate squares for dipping b/c thats what I had on hand.  I melted a box w/a little shorting and it worked just fine.  I used a melon baller for the scooping and shaping which was really easy.  Some people mentioned that they fell apart easy but, I never had that problem.  I also didn't refrigerate before I dipped, the chocolate didn't harden until I sat them in the freezer when I was all finished.  It only took about 15 min. until they were ready.  I can't wait to make these for a special occasion and decorate them really pretty.  I took a pic of them but didn't dress them up which they looked fine but there is a lot of potential there.  Thanks for this great recipe!

You also put the insides of the cookie (the cream) into the food processor.  The recipe wasn't clear on that and I had to think about it long and hard.  I was worried the cream would get stuck in the processor blades but in the end, it was finely grounded into the cookie crumbs.  I wouldn't sprinkle it with the crumbs at the end.  It's more attractive if you leave the chocolate shiny.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these last weekend for a birthday party, they were awesome! A lot of people mention having trouble with the dipping, I used a technique that worked for me...use one of those miniature ice cream scoops to form the balls, then stick them in the freezer for about half an hour. Take them out and stick toothpicks in them before dipping them in chocolate/toppings (I used chocolate sprinkles, they worked well), and then put them in mini cupcake papers and let them chill in the freezer again. You can either serve them with the toothpicks in, or take them out and turn them over for a more "perfect" look.

country:

text:
I have to disagree with so many people on here.  I'm shocked by this because I'm really not a great cook and I usually make a mess of the kitchen when I do use it!  This took me from start to finish almost exactly 1 1/2 hours. I used Nutter Butters as some other people suggested so I don't know if the peanut butter makes them stick together better than the Oreo filling, but I had no problem rolling them or covering them with the melted chocolate.  I put the mixture in the freezer for like 10 minutes before making the balls (rolled with my hands) but I didn't freeze/chill the balls after I made them.  I went right ahead and stuck a toothpick into them and dipped them right into the chocolate.  They didn't fall apart at all. Some stuck on the toothpick a bit when I tried to put them on the cookie sheet I was using, so I gently helped them off with another toothpick.  I'd say this isn't super fast, but it was really easy and I don't even own a microwave so I had to melt the chocolate right on the stove.  As for the taste, it was very chocolatey like some people mentioned, and mine were kind of dry.  Next time I'll probably use fewer Nutter Butters (or whatever I mix in there) and maybe more cream cheese.  Regardless, with the sprinkled topping, they look great and professional almost and were really, really easy I thought.   Thanks!  :)

None
text:
These were awesome! The store was out of Bakers baking chocolate so I got semi-sweet chocolate chips instead, they worked wonderfully. The dipping process was messy, slow and a little hard. At first I was using my hands, but they just fell apart, so I got a fork, placed a ball in the bowl and used the fork to scoop the melted chocolate on top of the ball. I found out that the more you moved the actual ball, the more it fell apart. So try and move the ball as little as possible. A great recipe, and I will definitely make again!!!

text:
I made this for a party and it was well received.  I got my recipe from another place and was told to use the candy chocolate you get at craft stores, don't worry about that, getting chocolate chips from the grocery store worked just as well. I covered mine with dark chocolate and then did a white chocolate drizzle over them after, so they were pretty. Only things I didn't like: 1. Dipping was a pain, maybe should have gotten that dipping spoon. Use something wider than a measuring cup, next time, i might try a square baking dish surrounded by a hot towel or something to keep the chocolate melty longer. 2. do not get water in your chocolate. 3. These are very rich so I suggest maybe dipping one half in dark chocolate, let them cool, dip the other half in white chocolate. 4. Next time I will use a non-chocolate cookie, maybe peanut butter or ginger snap.
