text:
YUMMY!! These are delicious, but you have to be a chocolate lover because these are so rich!! I did have with white chocolate, and half with semi-sweet. I melted my chocolate in the microwave- very easy, just 50% power and stir about every 30 secs. Also, put the oreo balls in the freezer while you melt the chocolate or you'll have melted oreo balls!! I bended all the oreos in the food processor first, then added the softened cream cheese. Very good!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very simple but time consuming, especially when you are making alot. I made 250 of these things for all of my staff and clients for the holidays. They each got a celephane bags with a few of these in them. Everyone raved about it, some even asked for the recipe. My advice is to freeze the balls on a waxed lined cookie sheet before and after dipping them in the chocolate and try to keep them partially frozen until you serve them. They taste much better. I also did not reserve any of the processed oreos for re-dipping. It seemed like an unnecessary step. To make them extra pretty, after you dip them in the chocolate and it sets, melt white chocolate and drizzle it with a fork on top for a very nice effect.

This was so super easy and got sooooooo many compliments!  This will be a go to recipe to wow a crowd.  I ground up the Oreos whole in the food processor - 10 at a time in a smaller one.  Then mixed with the cream chesse and put in the fridge for awhile.  Then I used a small cookie scoop to make the balls, then dipped in chocolate and put on wax paper to dry.  I just sprinkled the reserved oreos over the top and added some festive red sprinkles.  You cannot taste that these are oreos they just wos!  Sorry that I have to wait a year until the next cookie exchange - this is what I will be taking!

text:
These were pretty good.  I was expecting them to taste more like oreos and cream cheese but it really did not have that flavor exactly but a nice chocolatey flavor.  I attempted to do white chocolate but melted it wrong...i then mixed some milk chocolate and some white chocolate and drizzled with semi sweet.  I used a small melon baller to make the balls and then put them in the fridge. The dipping in melted chocolate was a chore and it probably did not help that I was rushing it.  I used skewers, that was probably the easiest. May try again with peanut butter too.

text:
These are ah-mazing!  I tried the 'batter' and thought they weren't so great.... but the finished product was fantastic.

I added a few peppermint Dove squares which gave a great subtle peppermint flavor.  I would totally do this again.

I think next time I would set aside less cookie crumbs as I had more than enough left over.  From 9 i would probably do 6 and thus add more to the mix.

I used Newman's wheat free "oreos" and it turned out well, just not as many "balls" since there are less cookies in the container.  I'm a big fan of this recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
dejastew
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

16
favoritesCount:
36
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/584625.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make a mint version for the holidays. I use regular oreos, blend them in the food processor, add about a teaspoon peppermint extract. Then I work in cream cheese with a spoon, then knead by hand to ensure a good mixture. I don't always chill them, but I let them sit in a stainless steel bowl, so I think the chill from the cream cheese remains. I use two bakers chocolate semi-sweet bars and melt in a double boiler with a couple of T of crisco to ensure a smooth texture. I added another 1/2 teaspoon of peppermint extract and topped the dipped balls with crushed candy cane.

text:
Variations - instead of Oreos, use: 
- 1/2 package crushed graham crackers plus 2 tbsp amaretto, covered in white chocolate
- 1 package crushed keebler pecan sandies plus 3 tbsp rum
- about 30 crushed vanilla wafer cookies plus 1/4 cup mini chocolate chips
- vanilla sandwich cookies, colorful sprinkles
- lemon sandwich cookies, key lime juice, 2 drops green food coloring (covered in white chocolate, rolled in graham cracker crumbs) 
- or add peppermint extract to the Oreos for a mint version

text:
I decided to mix this up and use the peppermint Oreos. It was a wonderful twist! I will say that I struggled at first because the batter was too soft to effectively dip in the chocolate. So I rolled the truffles into balls and put them in the freezer for about 25 minutes. I used chocolate chips that I melted in the microwave and they worked just as well. The only thing you have to be careful of is, make sure you are generous when dipping the balls or they will just end up frustrating you.???

Deborah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are amazing, but beware that they are not for the novice or impatient!  This was a 2 day project.  Your chocolate can easily harden, and it can be tough to wrap the oreo mixture in the chocolate sauce.  So be patient, and it if you make it to the end, you are likely to leave your guest in a chocolate coma!  We suggest trying to warp the oreo mixture in some other things such as caramel or peppermint bark (which surprisingly 5 different stores had never heard of!).  Those are easier to work with, and make the treats a little less sweet.  I chose to top them with a strawberry puree, which blended fabulously, and also made for a much more beautiful presentation than all black.  It is well worth all the effort.

Annie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4074207.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these twice now and my friend already asked me to make them for her baby shower.  I dont have a food processor so I blend the Oreo in my Ninja blender then I mix the cream cheese I put it in the fridge for over two hours then I take them out and roll them into balls.  I realized its best to put the chocolate in a cup and dip the Oreos in there makes it easier, then I immediately sprinkle the crush Oreos in there.  Im giving it four stars because the directions could have been better.  I brought lollipops sticks from party city you can get them from Amazon too that way it can be eaten as a cake pop.  I realized the best thing to do is once I roll them into the balls I dip the lollipops stick into the chocolate and stick the stick on the Oreos then I put it back in fridge to get harder.  It seem its a longer process but its worth it if you want to do the stick, if you doing them for a party you can do them the day before.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great! The only issue is that they did not make the serving amount shown. We made pretty regular sized balls (22g each) and only ended up with about 26 servings. I will make them smaller next time, (20g?) but not too much smaller. They were just barely too big for the little paper truffle cups. (The chocolate coating adds to the size of the balls more than I thought it would.) Also (note to self) white chocolate seemed more difficult to work with than regular chocolate. I used Tollhouse white chips. Maybe add a little oil? I did freeze them after the balls were formed. It took quite a while to get them all coated. (I tripled the recipe and it was 4 hours start to finish.) I used an icing bag with a tip to drizzle the white chocolate onto the dark and vice versa. Overall it was a lot of fun, and pretty easy. It would be fun to experiment with different types of candies/cookies. Thanks! :)

userID:
17074355
Display Name:
Shannon Holman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
18
favoritesCount:
34
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2999519.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy.  After reading reviews, I used nutter butter cookies and put the entire bag in a processor to pulverize.  I then added the room temp cream cheese and blended with the cookies in the processor.  meanwhile, I microwaved the chocolate in a plastic bowl and used a small spoon and fork to drop the small peanut balls in to the chocolate.  They stayed firm and I had no issues with them falling apart.  I put them on a wax paper covered cookie sheet after dipping them into the chocolate.  I also bought caramel peanuts and crushed them and sprinkled them on top of the finished balls before I put in the fridge.  They look great, they taste great and they were super easy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5801215.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are a holiday favorite around my house! I recommend using double stuff Oreos (these have never fallen apart for me), and making a batch using white chocolate bark, which is my favorite, and another with semi-sweet chocolate bark, which seems to be a hit with the kids.  For anyone who does not have a food processor, I made these in my mixer for years, using the paddle attachment, and that worked well.  Also, I've found that using two spoons helps when dipping the balls into the chocolate, so that you can completely cover them as you gently roll and scoop them through the chocolate. Add sprinkles for a fun and fancy garnish and people will believe you spent hours making them!

text:
This was extremely easy to make and turned out fantastically. Friend's kids were begging for seconds. Made a couple small adjustments: added a little over a teaspoon of Bailey's and added 1/4 cup of unsweetened cocoa powder to the Oreo mixture. This is a recipe that can be easily altered but just be careful about adding to much liquids to the instructed Oreo mix. If too wet, it will be hard to form the ball shape.

text:
These are delicious.  I mixed them up and then froze them in a single layer on a cookie sheet.  I then put them on a ziplock bag to dip later.  I used a different chocolate dip (chocolate chips and a tablespoon of shortening) and dipped them while frozen.  I read not to do that, but they turned out perfect.  I could see that if they sit out long they may get very soft, but I served them from the refrigerator and they were loved by all.

0
userID:
2404045
Display Name:
Tiffanie DeMayo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
59
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2866647.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These Oreo Truffles are amazingly easy to make, I started making them at Christmas about 7 years ago, and most people love them. Some DO say they are to sweet, so I made a few changes. First, I never tried making them with double stuff Oreos, I would think they wouldn't stay together.
 I use a regular size package of Oreos, 1 package of cream cheese, and I don't dip them in melted chocolate. I mix the Oreos & cream cheese in my food processor, then place the "dough" in the fridge overnight. I make the Oreo ball the next day, then roll them in powdered sugar, colored sprinkles, finely chopped coconut, and chopped nuts. Some people like the nuts, others like powdered sugar, this way everyone gets the one they like!  This Christmas I'm going to try wrapping some of them in marzipan, and some in vanilla sugar.  
 ( Vanilla sugar is two cups of sugar with the inside of two Madagascan vanilla beans, placed in a lidded jar, and shaken, then stored someplace cool & dry for a week, or longer)
Review:
Rating:
4

country:
None
text:
These are straight-up delicious. I put the Oreos in the food processor, then transferred the crushed cookies to a bowl and used a fork to mix in the cream cheese. I used a small cookie scoop to scoop small balls of dough onto a parchment lined cookie sheet. I just drizzled the melted chocolate on top - I skipped crushing the extra cookies for a topping and used sprinkles. Refrigerated for about 15 minutes. Done! As a side note, I noticed Oreos now has a lemon flavor and I think that would be delicious with a white chocolate drizzle and some lemon zest.

None
text:
I have made these several times in the last month by request of family members. These are amazing, rich, and delicious - even my family members who dislike sweets like these decadent truffles.
A few tips that I've learned:
-Refrigerate the dough for about 30 minutes before dipping in chocolate. This helps the chocolate harden quickly onto the ball and helps the balls retain their round shape.
-Use a tablespoon to scoop out the same size balls each time.
-Only serve these directly out of the fridge, otherwise they get way too soft (although still delicious)

text:
I had a batch of homemade Almond Butter cookies that were a couple days old and I thought...why not make Truffles for my Christmas Cookie Gift Tins?  Perfect!  Followed this recipe, using cream cheese and Almond Butter to make the frosting mixture.  Dipped in the chocolate - definitely add a little Cisco -and for finishing touches, a zip lock with a cutoff corner filled some melted white chocolate to quickly drizzle some prettiness over the top, a few red, white and green sprinkles and they looked and tasted like a million bucks!  Chilling of the filling before AND after rolling is the key to easy success!  Fantastic recipe, and the possibilities are endless!

Display Name:
HillCountryBrownlow

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2961530.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband loved this! I made it with a few changes based on concern that the cream cheese would taste odd in combination with the Oreo mixture. 
So, I used double stuffed Oreo. I put 5 rows of cookies in the processor and put aside 1/2 cup of the crumbles for garnish later. Then added 1/2 to 3/4 cup of cream cheese and about 1/4 cup of (pre-made) cream cheese frosting.  It's not exact, I was looking for the consistency of wet sand when I squished the mixture in my hand, but not too wet/sticky. I squished/formed it into dense balls, no rolling. Chilled in the freezer.  The chocolate used to coat made a difference. I started with chocolate bark I needed to use up and ended with a more expensive (Ghirardelli) brand of chocolate. The bark made a rough looking truffle but didn't melt when it touched my hand. The G chocolate made gorgeous, smooth truffles but melted more quickly. The end product was an Oreo truffle that tasted more Oreo than cream cheese but had a little bite to it. My hubs said it's the way Oreos should be. :) I hope this helps those who said it tasted weird like Oreo and sour cream....

text:
You need to refrigerate the dough a little first BEFORE you roll them into balls; then, freeze them BEFORE dipping them in chocolate. Otherwise, you will get a gooey mess as some have described. Also, making these with semi-sweet chocolate is not good. They are way too rich! I think white chocolate works best, but that is my opinion.

None
text:
These are so easy to make and came out absolutely delicious! My 7 year old practically made these himself. The trick is to make sure you freeze them for at least na hour before coating them with chocolate. I kept half in the freezer while I worked on the other half. We melted milk chocolate chips inthe microwave, in 30 second spurts, with 2 tablespoons of coconut oil. The chocolate was the perfect consistency. We used a chopstick to dip them, let the chocolate run off, then dusted them with different things: salt, dark chocolate, cinnamon. I don't even like oreos, but these are SO GOOD! I'm just hoping we have some left when our guests arrive!!! Oh, and like another reviewer said, they need to stay refrigerated until ready to serve.

text:
I've made these many times in the last 3 years and they are always a huge hit!  Every time I make them for a party people think I'm some kind of baking genius (and I'm no where close). After I mix the softened cream cheese and Oreos I set them in the fridge for about 30 minutes to cool them down (makes less crumbly balls). I use the entire Oreo bag and don't sprinkle crumbs on the top because I'm too lazy. I usually use about 4-6 packets of baking chocolate to get full coverage.  I also melt 2 packets at a time in different bowls to prevent burnt chocolate.   Yum!

I've been making these in the same way for the last 10 or so years, way before I ever saw this recipe, but this is how I do them, too! My dif is I used white chocolate (still the baking kind) to dip it in. It is a giant hit at parties and talk about guilty pleasures, haha. After loving these bad boys, I developed some food allergies/sensitivities so I now use gluten-free "oreos" (I prefer kinnikinnick's "KinniToos Chocolate Vanilla Sandwich Creme Cookies") plus non-dairy creme cheese (I like Tofutti's) and a non-dairy white chocolate (I like Oppenheimer's Vegan White Chocolate Chips). All directions are the same and you will not regret it whether you follow my tips or the wonderful author's great recipe. Thank you for posting this wonderful treat for all!

text:
I wouldn't  call this "easy".  The only easy part about it was using 3 ingredients.  The Oreos were easy to chop and mix with the cream cheese, but you have to get your hands dirty and dig in.  Rolling the balls was time-consuming, but not as sticky as I expected.  The hardest part was dipping them in chocolate.  Pieces of Oreo were falling off into the chocolate dip so it wasn't coating well, and forget about trying to roll them in the leftover Oreo crumbs afterwardsThey still tasted good though.  Very rich.

text:
Omg! This easy to do recipe makes me feel like a natural born baker..lmao
Soo good!! Big hit!! 
I read other reviews and found it a little odd that some had issues with the balls falling apart in the chocolate. That did not happen with me but i did roll and squick and re-roll the balls to make sure they were tight!!
I actually just put the oreos in a bag and beat the hell out of it lol
then "played" with it in a bowl with the cream cheese. I kept at it until it was a black blob! So I reeeally got in there!
Then shaped them and my sister melted chocolate for me. I used two spoons to coat and I just rolled it off the spoon..
They are sooo good but tasted more like oreo when it was left in the fridge for a few more hours. I could only eat a few they are sooo rich but gosh so good!
Very glad I came across this and will keep making for a very long time!!
Happy eating everyone!

text:
These little things are the best. They look and taste so sophisticated, your friends won't believe when (if) you tell them it's only three ingredients. As some of the others have said, I refrigerate the balls before coating them in chocolate.  If the chocolate is clumpy, warm just a tad longer until it is smooth when mixed. It will make for easier coating and prettier truffles. The one downside to this recipe is that it usually takes me a couple hours to get all the balls rolled and coated. Maybe I'm just slow.

None
text:
Everyone always begs me to make this again. Tip: A good way to crush Oreos is to put it into TWO (in case it breaks) plastic bags and slam it against the countertop. You can also lightly tap a hammer o it, just make sure you do that on a cutting board still in the two plastic bags. You can also make these into pops by putting toothpicks or popsicle sticks into them. If you do popsicle sticks, though, make them a bit bigger.
Review:

userID:
2382923
Display Name:
Kimberly
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
19
favoritesCount:
134
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/143732.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone always loves them. I have had some say they can be too sweet, but it's more personal preference. Some people like sweets, some prefer salty or savory. I switch the full flavor cream cheese for 1/3 fat or fat free. Sometimes I do a mix. Freeze them for a few hours before you coat them in chocolate. I usually grab a few at a time out of the freezer, dip, then grab some more. You don't want them to fall apart in the chocolate. Wax paper is your best friend while making these. After I dip them, I put them into the frig to completely cool. You can even make them like cake pops by dipping sticks into the chocolate and insert into the ball before refrigeration.

I love this recipe and it is a huge hit everywhere I take them! Instead of dipping them in chocolate, I pour the chocolate over them. It still covers well and has extra chocolate around the bottom. And my kids are able to help doing this way. 
I do chill for longer than an hour just to make sure they are good and hard and then chill again for over an hour. I do store them in the fridge instead of out just to make sure they stay together.

I really liked these truffles, (and so did the girls from my softball team) the recipe made a lot too. I didn't have baking chocolate so I tried using chocolate chips, they didn't melt very well and we had trouble coating the truffles but we managed to get a clean end result. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6588197.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had these at a pot luck we threw for my father's 64th birthday. They were phenomenal! I had to try them at home, and they were just as easy to make as they sound. Definitely use a food processor for all the mixing to get them super smooth (just like an expensive gourmet truffle) and chill the mixture before forming the balls, as the processor will warm it up a bit.

I saw one person commented that these can't sit out at room temperature and became "really gross" after 5 minutes on the counter. Not sure what happened with their batch. The ones at the potluck sat outside on an 80 degree day for half an hour and were fine. Though, I would definitely store them in the fridge when not eating them because of the cream cheese.

text:
Great simple recipe. Don't thaw cream cheese much. Use REAL chocolate. Freeze the mix for about 30 minutes before turning into balls. Might have to refreeze again half way through making the balls. Also, this recipe freezes really well. You can just make some ahead of time and have them on hand in the freezer.

text:
Much easier than it looks!  I would recommend white chocolate for the dip as it is much easier to melt and spread than regular chocolate.  Tastes better, too, in my opinion.  I used lollipop sticks in each to make the dipping process easier.  Took another reviewer's advice and only used regular Oreos (i.e., no double-stuff).  I made mine a bit larger, and only came out with around 30.  Don't think I'd want them much smaller.  Definitely a crowd-pleaser!

I've been making these for years... Use double stuff Oreos!   Tip stick balls in freezer for a few mins before dipping in chocolate (helps them from falling apart) .  These are always a huge hit. These are yummy, and very easy. The recommended 9 cookies for crumbs was way more than we needed - probably could have used half or a third of that and had plenty of crumbs to sprinkle. It was lovely to have a recipe they could help with and actually truly be helpful and save time, and they loved it.

text:
I made these and brought them to work for Christmas treats. Everyone loved them! I used a rolling pin since I didn't have a food processor. It took a while longer and there were larger pieces of Oreo because of this but they still turned out great. I think I may have coated them with too much of the chocolate because I did not have enough of the melted chocolate to cover all of them. I would suggest using a bit more if you like them really covered!

text:
Super easy, especially since I used a food processor! I read the recipe wrong and instead of sprinkling the cookie crumbs over the chocolate, I rolled them in it...turned out great anyways and I'm not sure I would choose to do it any other way!!I just went from rolling them/spooning chocolate over the ball to transferring them to a bowl of crushed crumbs and rolling them in there, then carefully taking them out with a fork. Very easy process with no chocolate dripping.

text:
Deeeelish! These were so great and I got rave reviews when I made them! I dipped them in Baker's milk chocolate dipping cups and it worked great. I then chilled them in the fridge until firm then drizzled white chocolate over them, then chilled again until ready to serve. I set aside the 9 oreos like the recipe called for, but didn't use them, the white chocolate drizzle was a lot prettier. These are super good, but very rich so don't forget the milk!

text:
Great, easy recipe!!! I have made it several times. Some tips are: not just mix but mush oreos and cream cheese for a smooth interior. mix for a more crunchy touch. When melting chocolate make sure to melt a little at a time, too much will make it solidify and unable to be melted again. White chocolate will make it prettier and then design with a darker chocolate.

This is by far the easiest and best truffles ever!  You cant go wrong with this recipe and the results are just amazing! I have made these truffles numerous times.. they are a hit every time!  I chop up the oreos in a food processor and add the cream cheese to the food processor to mix them together.  Roll little balls and put them in the refrigerator for a while.  I would recommend only taking about half out.. working with that half to dip in the chocolate and then take the other half out - its just easier to work with the truffles when they are cold! I have used white chocolate, vanilla, and chocolate for the coverings and different types of garnish.. you can really do anything - just simple recipe.. a keeper!

text:
Amazingly easy!  A must at work functions.  Put a row of oreos at a time into the blender & pulse it to crush it the quickest w/o burning up your motor.  Refridgeration does help.  Use a single fork to roll the ball in the chocolate & tap the ball off the fork onto the wax paper.  Sidenote - only use 4oz of creamcheese for specialty oreos as there's less in the pack.  Another great way to get mint flavor is to add creme de menth (to taste) to the chocolate. Very pretty as it turns white chocolate a pretty green color.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/594922.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is another YUMMY, EASY and EVERYONE LOVED it recipe!  This is a "get your hands sticky" kind of recipe.  A few things that I did differently was I scraped the cream from the cookie and set it aside.  I used the cream (a little larger than a pea) and shaped the cookie around it- for a nice creamy surprise when you bite into it (I hate to waste something so yummy and why not?!)  I used Smith/Kroger brand Chocolate Bark as Baker's tends to be a little thicker in consistency-which if that's the case, add oil (drop by drop) and mix well.  I used a glass (or ceramic) cup which keeps the chocolate warmer longer -if you don't have a double boiler.  I used a fork to fish them out of the cup-the spaces between it helps the excess chocolate drip off.  If you're a perfectionist, making the cookie as round and bump-less as possible is the key here, as the chocolate shell will only accentuate the lumps and bumps.  However, if you like the lumps and bumps- adding a few accented chocolate lines over the top of the truffle and drizzle some extra cookie crumbs on top will quickly detour the eye from imperfections and YUMMY nonetheless!

text:
Simply delicious! This was definitely the hit dessert for Easter! I used melted white chocolate chips to coat them and drizzled them with melted semi sweet chips in a ziploc bag with the tip cut off. I did however have trouble with the mixture starting to become undone, so make sure it's properly rolled and refrigerated for longer than an hour. Also with the white chocolate I added a tbs of vegetable oil to thin it and make it easier for dipping. Toothpicks helped a lot! Definitely give it a try the mixture is so delicious I could even eat it by itself!

text:
Great go-to recipe!  I've made these three times in the past month and they have disappeared in the blink of an eye all three times.  I use chocolate bark coating kept melted over a double boiler for dipping and it works like a charm.  The dipping is a bit time consuming, but it's worth it for the final product.  I will say that crushing 9 cookies for topping is a lot.  I used the crumbs I crushed for the first batch for topping all three batches.  The crumbs keep well in a air tight container, so it worked out well.  I can't wait to try this recipe using all the different flavors of Oreos.

text:
These were SOOOO rich and good.  Very simple to make.  I do recommend chilling the cookie mixture for a little while before dipping.  And my advise on dipping: Just put down a lot of newspaper on your counter, use a toothpick in the center of each ball, dip, swirl, and use a spoon so cover any missed spots.  Just set them down and they'll dry just fine.  Mmmmm.. Oreos and cream cheese...what more could you want?

text:
Fantastic!  Yummy!  I made these for Valentine's Day and they are excellent.  I used reduced-fat cream cheese and reduced-fat Oreos so I didn't feel SO gulity for eating them!  After rolling all the balls, I chilled overnight and that helped with the dipping.  I used milk chocolate Toll House chips instead of Baker's, but I think the center is what makes this goodie so good anyway!  I did have to add about a tablespoon of half and half so I could mix them with my hand mixer.  No food processor :(  Enjoy!

text:
AWESOME!!  These were so good I had people stopping by the house just to try them after hearing how good they were!  I didnt change a thing except using less oreos for the crumb topping.  Instead of 9, I used 4 and I still had more than enough left over.  I did, however, use all 36 oreos for the filling.  The dipping was a bit challenging so I used two forks to pick the balls up.  Dont be discouraged when you see the fork marks -- they get covered when the chocolate runs off.  After sitting in the fridge for a few hours they look amazing!  I will definitly be making these again....and again!

text:
These are SO good and extremely easy.  I make the truffles using the reduced fat oreos and 1/3 fat cream cheese and then freeze overnight before dipping into the melted chocolates with two forks and put them onto a wax paper lined cookie sheet.  The chocolate hardens quickly so make sure you sprinkle the crushed cookies on the wet choc. so it sticks.  I coat 6-10 at a time and then sprinkle the cookie crumbs.

These are SOOOOO easy and I got RAVE reviews from everyone.  I made 3 batches of these the first round for all the neighbors along with some other goodies and these were by far the favorites. After these were such a hit at Christmas I made another batch for our New Years party.  I used the limited edition candy cane oreos that only come out around the holidays and they were EXCELLENT! text:
Oh my gosh! Worth the effort! Absolutely delicious! My fiance discovered them before our family arrived for Christmas dinner and I thought there would be none left by the time they came!  Definitely refrigerate the cream cheese/oreo balls for about an hour or so before attempting to dip, otherwise they'll be too soft and fall apart. I melted 4 ounces of chocolate at a time so it wouldn't solidify while I was dipping, perhaps more time consuming but it worked for me. I didn't have a technical way of dipping other than dropping in a ball, rolling it around with small cappuccino spoons, and pulling it out. I'm looking forward to trying these again next year with the holiday flavoured Oreos!

region:

None
text:
I used good cream cheese and Ghiradelli chocolate and they were divine. Everyone loved them!! After mixing the cookies and cream cheese together and placing it in the frig for 30 minutes. I then used a small scooper made for cookies, to get them all the same size, I scooped them out. Wore medical gloves and shaped them into balls without any problems whatsoever. Again in the frig for 30 minutes then dipped them with a candy dipper into the Ghiradelli chocolate. Very simple and I did not have any problems with them falling apart and no cookies under my nails.

text:
Warning - these are addicting!  I don't have a large food processer, so I crushed the cookies in a ziplock.  Then I whipped the cream cheese in my electric mixer and added the crushed cookies and beat until it came together.  I also used a small cookie scoop to make sure they were all the same size, then rolled into balls.  I dipped in dark chocolate and almond bark.  We liked the almond bark best.  So easy and fantastic!
Review:
Rating:
4

2009-12-27T07:55:24.68

text:
These are so incredibly decadent, people never believe how easy they are to make.  I have made them with both white and milk chocolate and both are equally delicious.  I love how fancy they look-  they are perfect for gift-giving in a pretty holiday plate wrapped with cellophane.  I find that the best way to mix the cookie crumbs and cream cheese is to dig right in with my hands.  Then I pop it in the freezer for about 15 minutes, which makes rolling them into balls a cinch!  I'm sure I will make these many times!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/479549.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A co-worker made these but slightly different.  They were so amazing i had to make some myself! Some things I do different that I think makes it easier is- I use 1/3 less fat cream cheese... still sweet but not as sweet or oily.  I also use milk chocolate from melted chocolate chips.  I mix one box of cream cheese with one box of crushed oreos and refrigerate.  After they are chilled, then roll them and dip them.  I put them in the chocolate, roll them with a spoon and "plop" them on waxed paper.  They arent as "pretty" but so yummy!  And refrigerate after.  I dont add the crumbs to the top, just seems like more effort then needed.  I have also made them with mint oreos... I love mint and these surprizingly have a very slight hint of mint, which is also very nice!

Okay... maybe I'm missing it, but no where did I read that you were supposed to add the oreo filling back into the mix with the cream cheese. I'm sure you can all see where this is going, but I'll say it anyway. Yes... I did forget it!! Also, just so you know... it did taste gross, but what a recipe!! I had already coated the candies in chocolate, and knew they weren't going to be any good, so I just threw them back in the mixer, and added the cookie filling back into the mix. It turned out (even though I had coated it with chocolate)!! I will make this again, and next time it will be done correctly!! :)

These taste amazing! However, I rated it 4 stars due to proportions stated in the recipe. I was able to get by with one 8 oz box of chocolate. I bet these would be even more amazing in white chocolate.

text:
These truffles are incredibly simple to make and have a very rich flavour. I halved the recipe, using only half a box of double stuff oreos (my favourite) and half a brick of cream cheese, which yielded about a dozen truffles. I froze the cookie/cream cheese mixture for about an hour as per the other reviews and it made it much easier to form and dip them. I'm looking forward to trying a variety of cookies and toppings. Thank you very much for sharing!

text:
Awesome!  A little messy when dipping in chocolate. I found rotating between two forks when removing the truffle to wax paper worked pretty well.  I made my first batch using white chocolate...incredible flavor.  My second batch I made using Oreo Peanut butter cookies.  I added maybe a 1 1/2 tablespoons of creamy peanut butter as well and then dipped in semi-sweet...I have two words for you..."YUM MEE"!!

text:
I have also been making these truffles and various other truffles using the same technique, for years.  They are always the first to go.  Just to add: I have the best luck dipping using a fork and then pouring the chocolate over the ball with a spoon.  I also like to use white and regular chocolates and decorate with drizzles of the other, jimmies and the like.  You can't go wrong with this easy recipe.  Oh, wanted to add: if your chocolate gets hard just keep nuking for a few seconds to re-melt and add a couple drips of milk if necessary to thin it out.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are so easy considering how nice they look and how yummy they taste! The only hard part is getting the chocolate coating onto the rolled balls. Everyone has their own favorite method--I found a fondue skewer helpful to hold the ball while I ladled the chocolate on with a spoon. My husband used the two-spoon method (cup it with one spoon while rolling it around in the chocolate with the other). We drizzled white chocolate over them once they'd set, and they look very elegant that way. I haven't tried making them with peanut butter cookies yet, but it sounds delicious!

text:
Very easy to make. I used milk chocolate instead of semi-sweet chocolate. I first made the dough (creamcheese and oreo mix) and left it in the fridge for 20 minutes. Then I made them into balls and put it back in the fridge for another 30 minutes so they get firm. I used a double broiler to melt the chocolate. I also used a fork to dip the balls in the chocolate. They didn't fall apart and it was easy to get a nice coating all around. Instead of sprinkling with oreo crumb...i sprinkled nuts instead. They came out great and tasted delicious.

take them out in 10 minutes, take the truffles out of the toothpick and drizzle it with white chocolate.. Yumm

text:
Easy and delicious. Scooped out the cream cheese/cookie mix into little balls and froze them on a cookie sheet. After they had hardened, I melted the bark, dropped one ball in at a time, and used a fork to scoop the balls out. Laid it back on the cookie sheet, sprinkled the crushed oreos on top and placed it back in the fridge. Had to work fairly quickly but it turned out awesome :)

text:
Super Easy and relatively fast (I did freeze before dipping and used a spoon and a fork for the process). Sprinkled some with chopped pecans and decorated some with white chocolate strips. To do the strips: Put a few (about 20 chips)white chocolate chips in a ziploc bag and push them all the way to one corner. Microwave 30 seconds at a time until they melt, squeeshing with your fingers everytime. Snip off the corner (not too small or the bag will pop when you squeeze it) and using fast side by side movements draw lines on top of the truffles. Drawback: TOO RICH! OMG!! Even without chocolate on top!!

text:
This is AWESOME! Well worth the work, but still VERY easy to make. It was simple for me to do, because I froze the balls before dipping for about 40 minutes on a tray lined with wax paper. I used a fork for dipping, and let the excess chocolate run off before placing back on the wax paper. I used Chocolate Almond Bark which works so well. By the way I only used 30 cookies, instead of 36 mixed with the cream cheese, because I knew it would hold together better when dipping. All I can say is YUM!!!!

userID:
3679092
Display Name:
ArasJ
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
No matter what anyone says... DO NOT USE MORSELS - use the best quality chocolate.  The recipe that I used to make these was the same, but it called for morsels, not Baker's.  It was a nightmare to dip the balls in the chocolate.  They looked clumpy and absolutely horrible.  After trying a few, I improvised with good quality milk chocolate and they were SO much easier to dip.  Tasted great.  I also drizzled with white chocolate, although the oreo crumbs would be fantastic. Word to the wise:  the smaller the balls, the better they taste.  If they are too large, they will taste too rich and cause a tummy ache!  Definitely a hit though!!
Review:

5

text:
A client of mine (while I was working at a weight loss center no less) gave me this recipe printed off the website several years ago. She went looking for it because someone in town was charging $12 a dozen for them and her friends loved them. I have since made them on many occasions and had requests to make them many more. While time consuming, this recipe is quite easy. The last time I made several batches for an event my husband even helped. (He was so proud)I do change one thing however, I don't like using semisweet chocolate, so I using milk chocolate molding discs. I actually gave these out in nice tins for Christmas one year and people kept asking where I bought them! These are a huge hit!

text:
I absolutely love these - but a warning, unless you love chocolate you might not feel the same way.  I've taken them to a party and people either LOVED them or thought it was way too much chocolate.  Also, if you drizzle white chocolate on them it is easier to melt the chocolate and then put them in a ziploc bag with a tiny end cut off - it makes it so much easier and nicer.  I colored the white chocolate red/green to make them more festive.  Will make again and again!!
